Row.Text: Andelsbevægelse

+10% [ICON_PRODUCTION] Production when constructing Buildings in this City. 10% of [ICON_FOOD] Food created by the City counts as [ICON_GOLD] Gold Per Turn. The [COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]Farming[ENDCOLOR] Process is 15% more effective at converting [ICON_PRODUCTION] Production and reducing [ICON_HAPPINESS_3] Distress.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]+1 [ICON_FOOD] Food to Grass and Plains tiles near the City. +2 [ICON_FOOD] Food, [ICON_PRODUCTION] Production, and [ICON_GOLD] Gold to Nearby Farms and Pastures.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Does not require [ICON_RES_HORSE] Horses.

The Andelsbevægelse is a Danish unique building which can speed up building production. The building's massive bonuses to growth help your empire to multiply, especially when surrounded by plains and pastures.

The Andelsbevægelse was a Danish Cooperative Movement, corporations where individual members each owned a share in the risks and profits of the collective. Co-ops, as they are commonly referred to, continue to be popular in the farming industry as a way of mitigating bad harvests on the part of a few members. [NEWLINE][NEWLINE]After the disastrous Second War of Schleswig where Denmark lost considerable territory, Denmark began to reclaim moors in central and western Jutland for farming. Shortly after, the rapidly industrializing United States began pouring exports of grain into Denmark's biggest customer, Great Britain, tanking the prices for Denmark's produce. With the livelihoods of many Danish farmers at risk, they formed a new strategy to switch from grain products to dairy and meat. [NEWLINE][NEWLINE]This shift in Danish agriculture was full of uncertainty, requiring that farmers form the Andelsbevægelse to share in the risks. By the time prices for grain had finally stabilized, Danish agriculture had completely changed. Dairies and slaughterhouses dotted the landscape; now they were IMPORTING grain from Russia to feed their livestock!
Proxenos
+5 [ICON_INFLUENCE] Influence and +2 [ICON_GOLD] Gold in Capital on completion of [COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]Diplomatic Mission in City-State's territotry[ENDCOLOR].
Agora

+25% [ICON_PRODUCTION] Production towards Diplomatic Units in this City. Diplomatic Units trained in this City receive the [COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]Proxenos[ENDCOLOR] Promotion.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][ICON_INTERNATIONAL_TRADE] Trade Routes other Players make to this City will generate +1 [ICON_GOLD] Gold for both the City Owner and the Trade Route Owner.[NEWLINE]Nearby [ICON_RES_SPICES] Cinnamon: +1 [ICON_FOOD] Food and +1 [ICON_PRODUCTION] Production[NEWLINE]Nearby [ICON_RES_SUGAR] Sugar: +1 [ICON_FOOD] Food and +1 [ICON_GOLD] Gold.

Unique Market replacement for the Greeks. In addition to the normal bonuses of a Market, the Agora boosts the production Diplomatic Units. Diplomatic units trained in a city with an Agora gain the Proxenos promotion, which increases influence and gold income from Diplomatic Missions. Use your quick production of diplomatic units to secure a steady stream of gold for your empire.

The Agora was the marketplace and beating heart of the ancient Greek city-states. Originally used as meeting places for announcements and a muster point for soldiers, Agoras gradually became centers of commerce and trade. Artisans and merchants could sell their wares either in the open, or along the covered walkways which surrounded the field, known as the stoa.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE] Often the site of intense philosophical and political discussion, the Agoras have been immortalized as the proving ground of renowned philosophers, writers, storytellers, and orators. Disciplines such as Sophism, Skepticism, Cynicism and Stoicism can trace their roots back to the politicking and squabbles of the Grecian Agora.
Six-Horns Council

Gain +25 [ICON_RESEARCH] Science as an instant boost whenever a Building is constructed in City, scaling with Era. Provides 2 [ICON_RES_IRON] Iron.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]All Stables gain +2 [ICON_CULTURE] Culture and +2 [ICON_PRODUCTION] Production. Receive +6 [ICON_HAPPINESS_1] Happiness for 20 turns and +100 [ICON_GOLD] Gold as an intant boost whenever you successfully demand Tribute from a City-State, scaling with Era. Bonus resets on each new Tribute.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Does not require any prerequisite building. The [ICON_PRODUCTION] Production Cost and [ICON_CITIZEN] Population Requirements increase based on the number of Cities you own.

The Six-Horns Council is the Hunnic Unique Wonder, replacing the Ironworks. In addition to the normal bonuses of the Ironworks, the Six Horns council increases Science and Culture, and boosts Culture and Production from all Stables on empire. The wonder provides additional Gold and Happiness from demanding tribute from minor City-States.

The Huns' origins remain shrouded in mystery, but one clue to their Xiongnu heritage is their rule by an Alti Cur, or "Six-Horns Council". The Alti Cur was a small council of nobles, the most powerful men within the Hunnic Empire besides the emperor himself. Each was seated according to their standing with the emperor, with the emperor's favorite seated to his immediate right.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE] An emperor's legitimacy depended heavily on the tributes he could extract from the surrounding kingdoms and distribute to his nobles. It is surmised that insufficient tributes from the Chinese and other client tribes triggered the decline and disappearance of the Xiongnu in East Asia, only for them reappear as the Huns of Eastern Europe.
Demanding tribute from the city-state has earned you {1_Num} [ICON_GOLD] Gold and +6 [ICON_HAPPINESS_1] Happiness for 20 turns!
Alti Cur tribute bonus
+6 [ICON_HAPPINESS_1] Happiness for 20 turns.
Santa María
Unit gains [ICON_GREAT_ADMIRAL] Great Admiral Points [COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]on Kill[ENDCOLOR].
Invincible
+6 [ICON_STRENGTH] Combat Strength if [COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]at full Health[ENDCOLOR]. -1 [ICON_ARROW_RIGHT] Moves. Lost after unit upgrade.
Armada

A Slow, but incredibly dangerous ship. Only the Spanish may build it.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Available earlier, but more expensive than the Corvette it replaces. Gains additional strength when at full HP. Begins with [COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]Boarding Party I[ENDCOLOR] and [COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]Boarding Party II[ENDCOLOR].

The Armada is a powerful ship in its era. You are unlikely to chase down an enemy, but brilliant maneuvering could force an engagement. Much more imposing when at full health, make sure to make contact with the enemy before they can get a few ranged shots or you will lose a great deal of power in your initial melee combat.

The "Great and Most Fortunate Navy", the Spanish Armada, was a fleet of 130 ships constructed for the invasion of England and the overthrow the tyrannical Reformist, Elizabeth I. The Armada was one of the largest fleets ever seen in Europe, raised at great expense by Philip II in retribution for England's break from the Catholic Church, their execution of Mary, Queen of Scots, their support for the Dutch revolt against Spain, and the illegitimacy of Elizabeth I.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE] Spanish ships were outnumbered by England’s navy, but they easily outgunned the smaller English vessels. In the end, however, it was not firepower, but speed which won the day, allowing the small English vessels to harry the lumbering Spanish Juggernaut, sinking 10 ships. When finally forced to retire to Spain, a navigational error blew the Armada off-course and onto the Irish coast, where fierce storms dashed the ships against the rocks. When the Armada at last reached Spain only 67 of the original 130 ships remained, full of sickly, starving, and demoralized sailors.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE] The lessons of the Spanish Armada informed naval strategy for the next two centuries. Cannons and ranged action had now overtaken boarding and ramming as the primary methods of attack; sinking, rather than capturing, was now the priority. With this stunning victory, England had wrested naval dominance from Spain, a lead they would maintain until the rise of the United States in WWII.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE] "I sent the Armada against men, not God's winds and waves".[NEWLINE] -Philip II
Elephant Camp

+1 [ICON_GOLD] Gold and +1 [ICON_PRODUCTION] Production to all Forests worked by this City. +1 [ICON_PEACE] Faith to Camps and +1 [ICON_CULTURE] Culture to Lumber Mills and Logging Camps near this City.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]+1 [ICON_PRODUCTION] Production for every 10 [ICON_CITIZEN] Citizens in this City. Internal [ICON_PRODUCTION] Production [ICON_INTERNATIONAL_TRADE] Trade Routes from this City generate +4 [ICON_PRODUCTION] Production.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]+1 [ICON_GOLD] Gold and +1 [ICON_PRODUCTION] Production in City for every 2 Strategic Resources imported from City-State Allies. +10 [ICON_PRODUCTION] Production and +10 [ICON_CULTURE] Culture whenever a City-State gifts a Unit, scaling with Era.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Allows [ICON_PRODUCTION] Production to be moved from this City along [ICON_INTERNATIONAL_TRADE] Trade Routes inside your Civilization.

The Baan Chang is the Siamese unique replacement for the Workshop. In addition to the normal bonuses of a Workshop, The Baan Chang increases Culture from lumber mills and logging camps, and gives Faith from Camps. [NEWLINE][NEWLINE]City-State gifts, both Strategic Resources and Units, provide additional benefits in cities with a Baan Chang, so be sure to make strong alliances to get the most from this building.

Often thought of as ceremonial and military implements first, perhaps the greatest contribution of elephants to human society has been as beasts of burden. Elephants are prized as a labour force even in modern times for their ability to haul the dense teak lumber found only in Burma and Thailand. The strength of a fully grown elephant is matched only by its grace, navigating difficult and uneven terrain while carrying heavy loads. With their delicate command of the forest trails, elephants also reduce the potential damage of logging roads to the surrounding forest.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE] The jobs of Southeast Asia's working elephants have come under threat within the past few decades with the mechanization of logging. Elephants and their mahouts have been forced to look for work in tourism and religious festivals, jobs which elephants find terribly stressful.
Bastu

The Swedish Bad Stuga (bath cabin), or Bastu, is a small cabin designed as a bathing and dry heat spa. A stove or furnace heats the room to 200°F before patrons enter, where they will recline and sweat. Bastus are a social affair, places for discussion and relaxation with family and friends, but were also places for food curing and childbirth in earlier times.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE] It is not known where or when Scandinavian sweat baths were first created, but it was well before the Christianization of Scandinavia, as evidenced by their ubiquity throughout medieval Europe. By the time written accounts first described Scandinavian sweat baths, Nordic countries had already created varied and distinct cultures surrounding them.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE] The health benefits of heat baths are many and varied. Sessions have been shown to relieve cold symptoms and increase pain thresholds. They also help with rheumatic pain and fatigue, and may even reduce the risk of dementia. Prolonged use of a sauna has been linked to reduced male fertility, however, and heat baths should never be enjoyed while under the effects of alcohol.

Unique Swedish replacement for the Baths. In addition to the bonuses of the Baths, the Bastu provides bonuses for lakes and tundra. Science and Culture is generated whenever a citizen is born, and extra Food is generated during Golden Ages. Unlike the Baths, the Bastu does not require a river,

+1 [ICON_RESEARCH] Science to Lake Tiles and +1 [ICON_RESEARCH] Science for every 2 Tundra Tiles worked. Gain 25% of the [ICON_RESEARCH] Science and 15% of the [ICON_CULTURE] Culture output of the City as an instant boost when a [ICON_CITIZEN] Citizen is born in this City.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]+1 [ICON_GOLD] Gold and +1 [ICON_CULTURE] Culture to Temples, Amphitheaters and Gardens in this City. +10% [ICON_CULTURE] Culture and [ICON_FOOD] Food in the City during [ICON_GOLDEN_AGE]Golden Ages.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Does not require a River.
Mingghan
+5 XP [COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]on Pillage[ENDCOLOR]. +20% [ICON_STRENGTH] Combat Strength if unit is standing [COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]on Pillaged Tile[ENDCOLOR].
Black Tug
Aggressive and menacing Medieval Era Mounted Melee Unit. Only the Mongols may build it. It is stronger against Wounded Units or while standing on Pillaged Tiles. Gains additional XP for pillaging.

Black Tug is a Mongolian unique unit, replacing the Knight. It is stronger and deals more damage to wounded units, and while standing on pillaged tiles. As mounted unit, the Black Tug is vulnerable to Pikemen.

A tug is a pole with circularly arranged horse tail-hairs of varying colors arranged at the top -- a symbol of the importance of horses in Mongol life. A white-haired banner is used as a peacetime symbol, while the black banner was for wartime. The original white banner disappeared early in history, but the black banner survived as the repository of Genghis Khan's soul. The Mongols continued to honor the banner, building a monastery to guard it, but the tug was eventually lost amidst the Stalinist purges of Mongolian nationalists, monks, and intellectuals in 1937.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE] The Nine White banners of Mongolia were revived after democracy was adopted in the early 1990s, replacing the previous communist flags. The modern Mongolian nine white banners are kept in the Government Palace in Ulaanbaatar; the modern Mongolian black banners are kept in the Ministry of Defense.
Embrasure
+33% [ICON_RANGE_STRENGTH] Range Combat Strength [COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]on Garrison in the City[ENDCOLOR].
Barbican

Replaces both the Armory and the Castle.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Requires Walls in this City. +1 [ICON_PRODUCTION] Production for Quarries worked by this City. Empire [ICON_HAPPINESS_3] Needs Modifier is reduced by 5% in this City and -1 [ICON_HAPPINESS_3] Unhappiness from [ICON_PRODUCTION] Distress. +25 XP for all new Units trained in this City. +20% [ICON_RANGE_STRENGTH] Ranged Combat Strength for City Bombardment and +33% [ICON_RANGE_STRENGTH] Ranged Combat Strength for Ranged units, and Siege Units garrisoned in this City.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Contains 1 slot for a [ICON_GREAT_WORK] Great Work of Art.

Unique Polish replacement for both the Castle and the Armory, but a bit stronger than both. Must have built Walls in the city. In addition to the city defense and unit training bonuses, the attacks of Ranged and Siege units garrisoned in the city are increased.

A Barbican is a fortified outpost or archery tower, forming part of a city’s outer defense. The towers were often situated with a clear line of fire towards the city’s gates, and connected to the city walls via a walled road called the ‘neck’. The most famous barbican was built in Kraków in 1499 during the reign of Jan Olbracht. Its construction took inspiration from two other Barbicans in Torun (1429) and Chelm (1449), and was built in response to the danger posed by encroaching Ottoman and Wallachian forces.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE] Barbicans became obsolete in the 15th century due to improvements in siege tactics and artillery. The Warsaw barbican, erected in 1540, was an anachronism long before it was completed. The tower was used only once by the Swedish in 1656, while trying to prevent Poland from retaking the city. The Swedish had captured the city without a fight two years prior.
Legatus Legionis
+1 [ICON_ARROW_RIGHT] Movement [COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]if unit [COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]starts turn within 2 tiles from Great General[ENDCOLOR].
Siege Mobility
+1 [ICON_ARROW_RIGHT] Movement.
Cacador

The Cacadores were the elite light infantry of the Portuguese army in the 18th and 19th centuries. The divisions were famed for their marksmanship and their brown coats, one of the first attempts at military camouflage. After Portugal's sound defeat and occupation by Napoleon, the English intervened on behalf of their ally to rally and reorganize a joint war to retake the country. The British general, William Beresford, formed the Cacadores to fill a skirmishing role analogous to the German jaegers or American ranger divisions. Under this combined military, the Cacadores helped in reclaiming Portuguese independence and distinguished themselves as the "fighting cocks" of the Portuguese army until the units were eventually dissolved in the military reforms of 1911.
The Cacador is the unique Portuguese replacement for the Gatling Gun. It gains recon promotions by leveling up, allowing it to excel in hostile terrain.

Ranged unit of the Industrial era. Only Portugal may build it. Whenever it levels up, it gains a random Promotion from the Trailblazer or Survivalism lines. Starts with [COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]Covering Fire I[ENDCOLOR].
Fighting Cock
Unit gets a free Trailblazer or Survivalism promotion [COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]on Levelling[ENDCOLOR].
Buffalo Pound

Available at Trapping. Can be built anywhere, including Cities with a Water Mill.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]+1 [ICON_FOOD] Food for every 5 [ICON_CITIZEN] Citizens in the City. A [ICON_RES_BISON] Bison Resource appears near the City. [NEWLINE]Nearby [ICON_RES_HORSE] Horses: +1 [ICON_FOOD] Food. [NEWLINE]Nearby [ICON_RES_SHEEP] Sheep: +1 [ICON_FOOD] Food. [NEWLINE]Nearby [ICON_RES_COW] Cattle: +1 [ICON_FOOD] Food. [NEWLINE]Nearby [ICON_RES_BISON] Bison: +1 [ICON_FOOD] Food.

The Buffalo Pound is the Shoshone unique building, replacing the Well. In addition to the normal bonuses of the Well, the Buffalo Pound provides food from Horses, Cattle, Sheep and Bison. It can also be constructed in cities with access to fresh water, even if a Water Mill has already been built there.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Buffalo will only spawn on flat plains or grassland tiles, with or without Forest.

Buffalo Pounds were large constructions built by many Plains Tribes for the entrapment and killing of Buffalo. Large herds of buffalo were corralled and funneled into the pound, a sturdy circular ring of hides and wood, where tribesmen could throw spears and other missile weapons from the safety of the walls.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE] Buffalo were a staple food source on the North American Plains, but hunting such large animals was difficult without horses or sturdy weapons. With the arrival of Europeans and the introduction of the horse and musket, Native American tribes could travel great distances and attack bison herds with impunity. The good times would not last, however, as Europeans encroached upon this way of life. Increasingly, the Great Plains were converted into farms and pastures for American homesteaders. The American buffalo was driven to the brink of extinction by a combination of habitat loss, industrial-scale hunting, and culls engineered to starve the indigenous population.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE] Today, American buffalo have recovered, but their range has been greatly limited to a few national parks. Commercial farming and sport hunting continues, but the buffalo are unlikely to ever return to their historical numbers.
Chaebol

City must have a Bank. +1 [ICON_GOLD] Gold for every 2 [ICON_CITIZEN] Citizens in the City and +2 [ICON_GOLD] Gold for Towns near the City. Cost of [ICON_GOLD] Gold purchasing in this City reduced by 10%. +3 [ICON_PRODUCTION] Production for Factories in this City.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]+2% [ICON_GREAT_PEOPLE] Great People Points for every [ICON_INTERNATIONAL_TRADE] International Trade Route controlled by the Empire.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Each Chaebol gains +2 [ICON_GOLD] Gold, [ICON_RESEARCH] Science, and [ICON_CULTURE] Culture in the city for every Chaebol on Empire.

The Chaebol is the unique Stock Exchange replacement for South Korea. In addition to the normal bonuses of a Stock Exchange, the Chaebol boosts the production of Factories in Cities where the Chaebol is built. Chaebols increase the production of Great People for every International Trade Route the Empire controls. In addition, every Chaebol increases the Gold, Culture and Science of every other Chaebol in the empire; the more you build, the more they produce.

Chaebol are powerful multi-national corporations originating in South Korea. Beginning as family businesses, generous government investment allowed the Chaebols to quickly industrialize South Korea's agricultural society, in what was to be called the miracle of the Han River. The Chaebol became central to the South Korean economy and came to represent the invincibility of South Korea’s industrial might until the financial crashes the late 20th century, which saw several important Chaebol declare bankruptcy.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE] Chaebol continue to dominate the South Korean economy and social fabric, and some like Samsung and Hyundai have become household names worldwide. Today, Chaebol account for over 80% of South Korea's exports, and the largest single Chaebol accounts for 17% of the entire nation's GDP.
Chasqui

Flexible Scout of the Classical Era. Only the Inca may build it. Heals an additional 10 HP, and gains +1 [ICON_ARROW_RIGHT] Movement in Friendly Territory. Moves at Double Speed in [COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]Mountains[ENDCOLOR].

The Chasqui is the unique Scout replacement for the Inca. This unit moves quickly through Mountains and friendly territory. The Chasqui also heals 10 additional HP whenever it heals, making it recover very quickly when exploring or fighting.

The Chasquis were the messengers of the Inca Empire in charge of carrying messages and gifts up to 240 km per day through a form of on-foot Pony Express. In addition to their physical fitness, Chasquis were well-educated, able to translate the khipus, the Incan knot-based writing system, to each other and higher authorities.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE] Chasquis were dispatched along thousands of miles of Andean trails, taking advantage of a vast system of roads and rope bridges maintained throughout the mountains of Peru and Ecuador. Tambos, or relay stations, were used for the chasquis to stop at and transfer messages to the next chasqui. Each Chasqui carried a conch trumpet which was blown to signalling to a fresh chasqui that one runner was close so that they could prepare to run.
Chasquiwasi

+10 HP [COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]on Heal[ENDCOLOR].[NEWLINE]+1 [ICON_ARROW_RIGHT] Movement Point [COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]in Friendly Territory[ENDCOLOR].[NEWLINE]Double Movement in [COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]Mountains[ENDCOLOR]
Corsair

The Barbary Corsairs were Muslim pirates and privateers operating off the coast of North Africa who became infamous throughout Europe. Ranging throughout the Mediterranean and as far as Iceland, the Corsairs slaughtered livestock and captured Christians for sale in the slave markets of the Islamic world. The frequency and ferocity of these raids, or "Razzia" was such that long stretches of Italian and Spanish coast was abandoned for fear of abduction. It is estimated that some 1.25 million people were enslaved by Barbary corsairs between 1530 and 1780 A.D.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE] The scope of Corsair activity began to diminish in the latter part of the 17th century, as the more powerful European navies started to pose a real threat to the Barbary States. However, Christian shipping and coastline continued to suffer until the early 19th century. Following the Napoleonic Wars and the Congress of Vienna in 1814, European powers agreed upon the need to suppress the Barbary corsairs for good. The razzias finally ceased after the Second Barbary War between the Barbary pirates and the United States, the impetus for the creation of the US Navy.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE] "It is written in our Koran, that all nations which do not acknowledge the Prophet are sinners, whom it is the right and duty of the faithful to plunder and enslave; and that every mu'min (believer) who is slain in this warfare is sure to go to paradise."[NEWLINE] -Sidi Haji Abdrahaman, to Thomas Jefferson in reply to his demand for the protection of American merchant ships

The Corsair is the unique Moroccan replacement for the Corvette. It specializes in raiding and pillaging maritime trade routes, earning Food and Production for each enemy unit killed and trade route plundered. The unit can enter other Civilization's borders, even without an open borders agreement, which can be exploited to disrupt better protected trade routes.

Naval Unit specializing in disrupting maritime trade. Only Morocco may build it. Can enter Rival Territory. Gain [ICON_FOOD] Food and [ICON_PRODUCTION] Production whenever a Corsair Kills a Units, Pillages a Resource, or Plunders a [ICON_INTERNATIONAL_TRADE] Trade Route.
Razzia

Nearest Coastal Friendly City gains [ICON_FOOD] Food and [ICON_PRODUCTION] Production [COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]on Kill, Pillage or Trade Route Plunder[ENDCOLOR]. Unit [COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]can Enter Enemy Territory[ENDCOLOR] without Open Borders Agreement.
Epic
Unit gains [ICON_CULTURE] Culture and additional XP [COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]on Kill[ENDCOLOR]. [ICON_CULTURE] Culture doubled [COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]on Barbarian Kills[ENDCOLOR].
Dhanurvidya
Unit gains [ICON_CULTURE] Culture and [ICON_PEACE] Faith [COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]on Promotion[ENDCOLOR].
Dhanurgraha

Potent early Archery Unit. Only India may build it. Slightly stronger than Archer which it replaces. Gains [ICON_CULTURE] Culture and bonus XP for every kill, and gains [ICON_PEACE] Faith and [ICON_CULTURE] Culture when levelling up. [ICON_CULTURE] Culture from kills is doubled against Barbarians.

The Dhanurgraha is a powerful defense against early barbarians which helps India maintain its cultural and religious dominance in the early game. Seek out barbarians to kill for culture and faith, then turn on your neighbours if it suits you.

Archery was the most highly revered martial art of ancient India. Many of the culture heroes and gods of the Vedic texts describe archers of unparalleled skill, including Arjuna, Rama, Karna, and even Shiva himself. Traditional Indian bows are described as long, matching the height of their users, but without the tremendous strength of the Welsh longbow.
Greek Fire

[COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]After Attack[ENDCOLOR] Defending Enemy Unit is marked. [COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]At the beginning of its turn[ENDCOLOR] it takes an additional 10 "fire" damage for every mark. Effect can stack up to [COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]3[ENDCOLOR] times after battles with 3 different units.
Fire
Unit takes an additional 10 "fire" damage [COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]at the start of its turn[ENDCOLOR].
Huge Fire
Unit takes an additional 20 "fire" damage [COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]at the start of its turn[ENDCOLOR].
Raging Fire
Unit takes an additional 30 "fire" damage [COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]at the start of its turn[ENDCOLOR].
Dromon

A powerful early Naval Ranged Unit. Only the Byzantines may build it. Each attack by a Dromon inflicts an additional 10 damage at the beginning of the enemy unit''s turn, up to 3 attacks. Starts with [COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]Splash Damage I[ENDCOLOR] Promotion.

Bring flaming death to your enemies. Stronger than the Penteconter it replaces, and deals additional burning damage to both the target unit and any enemies near the Dromon. It cannot end its turn in Deep Ocean tiles outside of the city borders.

A modified form of the traditional galley, the Dromon was an integral part of the Byzantine navy throughout the empire's reign. Featuring both oar and sail power, the Dromon was highly maneuverable and agile, but also dangerously equipped for battle. Through the use of Greek Fire, a precursor to modern Napalm, the Byzantines used an early form of the flamethrower to strike fear in the hearts of any who opposed them on the sea.

E-temenanki

+25% [ICON_GREAT_PEOPLE] GPP in the City. +25 [ICON_CULTURE] Culture in the City as an instant boost whenever a [ICON_CITIZEN] Citizen is born and +50 [ICON_GOLDEN_AGE] Golden Age Points whenever a Policy is unlocked, scaling with Era. Gain 15% of the City's [ICON_FOOD] Food and [ICON_RESEARCH] Science output whenever you invest in a Building on Empire.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]+1 [ICON_RESEARCH] Science to all Monuments and +2 [ICON_FOOD] Food to all Shrines.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Requires Monument in City. Can only be built in the [ICON_CAPITAL] Capital. The [ICON_PRODUCTION] Production Cost and [ICON_CITIZEN] Population Requirements increase based on the number of Cities you own.

E-temenanki is the Babylonian Unique Wonder, replacing the National Monument. In addition to the normal bonuses of a National Monument, E-temenanki awards Food and Science whenever a building is invested on empire, so invest in buildings early and often. All monuments in empire gain +1 Science and all Shrines gain +2 Food. Available earlier than the National Monument

E-temenanki was the Ziggurat of Marduk, god of storms and head of the Babylonian pantheon. Ziggurats were religious temples erected in Mesopotamian cities as the literal dwelling places of each city's patron god. The Ziggurats were constructed to replicate the high mountains, where it believed the gods originally lived, in order to make the gods feel more at home.
Eagle

One of the two elite class of infantry (the other being the Jaguar Warriors) in the Aztec army, the Eagle Warriors were the bravest young men of noble birth and/or those who had taken the most prisoners in battle. Like the Jaguars, the Eagles used the atlatl, bow, spear and macuahuitl (wooden swords set with obsidian shards); unlike the Jaguars, the Eagles decorated their armor with eagle feathers and wore a headdress shaped like the head of an eagle with the beak wide open. Upon taking 20 prisoners – intact enough to serve as human sacrifice – a young warrior was eligible to become an Eagle Warrior, no doubt making his family very proud. Until the Spanish arrived with their cannons, muskets, and horses, the Eagle and Jaguar warriors were the toughest bullies on the Mesoamerican block.
The Eagle is the unique Aztec replacement for the Swordsman. It does not require Iron to build. It has increased vision, and has a chance of capturing defeated enemy units as Workers.

Strong, front-line Unit of the Classical Era. Only the Aztecs may build it. Does not require [ICON_RES_IRON] Iron. 25% chance of converting any unit killed into a [ICON_WORKER] Worker. Starts with the [COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]Sentry[ENDCOLOR] and [COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]Cover I[ENDCOLOR] Promotions.

Examination Hall

Perhaps the greatest legacy of Chinese culture is the Imperial Examination system with which the Son of Heaven's empire was staffed with civil servants for over two millennia. The Imperial examinations represented an attempt to create an aristocracy of learning, a remarkable advance over the warrior and hereditary aristocracies that dominated the rest of the world. Amounting to tests of rote memorization, the examinations required direct quotations of Confucian philosophy and ethics from the Five Confucian Classics. A scholar who obtained the highest degree, the jinshi, would have his memory trained to a tremendous degree.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE] As Western universities began to move away from their own classical tradition to embrace economics, engineering and natural science, China's scholarly efforts languished in the ancient literary past. Under pressure to modernize, the examinations were abolished in 1890, leaving behind a legacy as the first system of intellectual meritocracy the world had ever seen.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE] “We tried an experiment which is unique in the history of the world: We sought to rule this great country not by force, but by wisdom. And for centuries we succeeded.”[NEWLINE] -Anonymous Confucian Philosopher; excerpt from "On a Chinese Screen"

The Examination Hall is a Chinese unique building, replacing the Chancery. In addition to the normal bonuses of a Chancery, the Exam Hall boosts Great People generation in the city, adding Great Person Points to whichever great person currently has the most points in the city whenever a citizen is born.

+10% [ICON_PRODUCTION] Production of Diplomatic Units. Grants the [COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]Royal Signet[ENDCOLOR] Promotion to all Diplomatic Units built in this City.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]+1 [ICON_GOLD] Gold in City for every City-State Friend, and +2 [ICON_PRODUCTION] Production for every Ally.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Whenever a [ICON_CITIZEN] Citizen is born, gain +15 [ICON_GREAT_PEOPLE] points toward [ICON_GREAT_PEOPLE] Great Person with the highest progress, scaling with Era.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]+2 [ICON_GOLD] Gold to [ICON_GREAT_WORK] Great Works in this City
Fale Tele

+5 [ICON_RESEARCH] Science whenever a [ICON_CITIZEN] Citizen is born in this City, scaling with Era. +3 [ICON_FOOD] Food, [ICON_GOLD] Gold, and [ICON_CULTURE] Culture whenever a Building is Constructed in this City, scaling with Era.

Unique Council replacement for the Polynesians. In addition to the normal bonuses of a Council, the Fale Tele provides Gold, Food and Culture whenever a building is constructed in the city. Build the Fale tele as a first priority to maximize the bonuses for all later buildings.

Literally meaning "Big Building", the Fale Tele is typical of Samoan architecture. By decree of Tagaloa-lagi, the Samoan creator god, all dwellings were to be of circular design, in imitation of the dome of the heavens and the horizon. Fale Tele were the largest of Samoan buildings, designed to act as meeting places for chief councils as well as family gatherings, celebrations and ceremonies. Regular dwellings were constructed behind the Fale Tele, while a carefully maintained lawn spread in front as a larger gathering and social space for all villagers.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE] Samoan culture’s emphasis on openness is reflected in their architecture, with its circular layouts and no walls. Fales have become emblematic of wider Polynesian architecture, with small fale, or faleo'o, becoming ubiquitous on beaches throughout the Pacific.
Figs

Native to the Middle East and western Asia, Figs have been cultivated since ancient times, being one of the oldest plants cultivated by humans. Figs were common in Ancient Greece and spread to Rome where they formed a staple fruit for the lower classes. Figs are easy to preserve and are well-suited to forming condiments due to their high sugar content. It is perhaps this very association with the simplicity and poverty of common folk which saw figs fall from fashion in later periods.
Flax
Can be improved by Plantation. Spawns near a City on the construction of the Egyptian Nilometer

Flax is a food and fiber crop best known for its use in the production of linen. The crop was first domesticated in the Fertile Crescent and was cultivated extensively in Egypt, where the fabric became tightly bound to the local culture. Linen has a smooth texture, high lustre, and is cool to the touch. These characteristics linked it to religious and ceremonial purity within Egyptian rituals. Priests wore linen fabrics exclusively and mummies were wrapped in linen in preparation for the afterlife. Today, more durable textiles like cotton have largely replaced linen as a fabric, but the flax seed is still widely used for food and cooking oil.
Fusta
A small and fast compliment to the Great Galleas, rather than a replacement. Weaker, but cheaper, and does not contribute to Unit [ICON_GOLD] Gold Maintenance. May withdraw before melee attacks.

Fusta are quick, cheap, and do not cost any unit maintenance. Use these ships in combination with the bigger Galleass to monitor and protect your shipping lanes without causing an undue burden on your economy.

Fusta, or galliots, were small galleys with no more than 35 sailors. Exceptionally light and fast, the Venetians originally used them to maintain a standing navy against pirates, but the ship quickly became a favorite of the pirates themselves. The shallow draft, maneuverability and speed of the Fusta made them a legend throughout the Mediterranean.
Grande École

Requires University in the City. -1 [ICON_HAPPINESS_3] Unhappiness from [ICON_RESEARCH] Illiteracy. +1 [ICON_PRODUCTION] Production and +1 [ICON_RESEARCH] Science for every 2 [ICON_CITIZEN] Population in this City. +2 [ICON_PRODUCTION] Production to [ICON_GREAT_SCIENTIST] Scientist Specialists and +2 [ICON_RESEARCH] Science to [ICON_GREAT_ENGINEER] Engineer Specialists in this City.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Allows Archaeologists to be built in this City.

The Grande École is the French unique building, replacing the Public School. In addition to the normal bonuses of a Public School, The Grande École increases production for every citizen in the City, has more Scientist Specialist slots, and helps to generate Great Engineers. In addition, all Scientists generate more Production, and all Engineers generate more Science, making any city with a Grande Ecole a powerhouse of scientific and technical achievement.

The French Grande École are institutions of higher learning separate from the more conventional university system. These schools are highly selective, taking only the best and brightest French graduates, and barring entry by foreigners. Once accepted, students studying at a Grande École are considered public servants, paying little to no entrance fees and even receiving a monthly government stipend.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]The origins of the Grande Écoles lie in the French Revolution, where several military and technical écoles normale supérieure were established by distinguished French mathematicians and intellectuals. The idea was to open education to individuals based strictly on merit. By the 19th century a number of schools had sprung up for a wide array of disciplines including natural sciences, business and the humanities. The Grande Écoles continue to have a deep impact on French society, with approximately 10% of all Native-born French citizens graduate from these schools, including many of France's most renowned politicians, philosophers, scientists, and executives.
Hacienda

Available at Civil Service. Cannot be built next to another Hacienda. Provides [ICON_FOOD] Food, [ICON_PRODUCTION] Production and [ICON_GOLD] Gold. Grants additional bonuses for every adjacent map component:[NEWLINE] +2 [ICON_FOOD] - Bonus Resource,[NEWLINE] +2 [ICON_PRODUCTION] - Strategic Resource,[NEWLINE] +2 [ICON_GOLD] - Luxury Resource,[NEWLINE] +1 [ICON_CULTURE] - City.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]+1 [ICON_PEACE] Faith if City has a Mission.

Haciendas are colonial estates constructed by the Spanish for the administration and extraction of resources from their native subjects. Haciendas were based on grants of property and enterprise, rather than the strict grant of indigenous labor as described by the older Encomienda system. Haciendas were generally large estates, but the nature of the work varied from plantations, to mining, to factories.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE] The owner of a Hacienda was called a Hacendado, but the wealthy landowners rarely visited their holdings and preferred to live in nearby cities. Day-to-day operations of a Hacienda were the responsibility of hired managers. Some unusually large and profitable Haciendas were the property of the Roman Catholic Church, exacerbating tension between native laborers and their Christian taskmasters.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE] The Hacienda system was abolished in most countries after the dissolution of the Spanish Empire, but with mixed results. Efforts to break apart the large estates into individual holdings for subsistence farmers led to crushing poverty in some South American nations. In contrast, Latin American and Filipino Haciendas were mostly left intact, but without the same legal standing or permissions of their colonial past.

A dangerous scout with no penalty against Barbarians. Only the Maya may build it. Gains [ICON_RESEARCH] Science and [ICON_CULTURE] Culture with every Ancient Ruin explored. Starts with the [COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]Trailblazer I[ENDCOLOR] Promotion.

The Holkan is a quick and independent scout for the Maya. Because of their free Trailblazer I promotion, the Holkan explores more quickly, and gains experience more easily than the Pathfinders. Their increased power against barbarians makes Holkans capable of ranging farther and taking more risks than a normal scout. Use these units to grab ruins quickly, and gain an early scientific edge and cultural edge.

The Maya are often idealized as a peaceful civilization by western Mayanists, but the Maya were no strangers to war. Unlike the wars of Europe and Asia, however, the Maya engaged in a highly ritualized form of combat based on astrological and religious concerns as much as political ones. Squabbles over land, influence and resources were common, but the capture of human sacrifices was another factor leading to war. [NEWLINE][NEWLINE]The nobility and priesthood of Mayan cities kept a monopoly on violence, making all but the most desperate of wars strictly within the affairs of the upper class. Weapons made of obsidian and chert were stockpiled within the palaces of lords and kings, who would call upon their family to lead raids. The leaders of such expeditions were known as ‘Holkan’.

Great Bombard

An Incredibly powerful Unit capable of smashing Cities to pieces. Only the Ottomans may build it. Does very high damage to Cities and Naval Units, but is less useful against Land Units compared to other Siege Weapons.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Deals 20 damage to itself on attack, but heals an additional 10 HP when in Friendly Territory.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Player may have only [COLOR_GREEN]2[ENDCOLOR] Great Bombards at one time.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]
The Great Bombard is a powerful Siege Weapon well after it is researched. It is the most powerful seige unit in its era; so dangerous it even hurts itself! Devastating against cities and naval units.

Bigger is better, and biggest is best. The super-sized bombards of the late medieval were first used in Western European warfare at the beginning of the 15th century, but it was the Ottomans that would realize the bombard's full potential at the Siege of Constantinople in 1453. Unable to find patronage with the Byzantine emperor, a Hungarian gunfounder named Orban sold his services to Mehmed II of the Ottoman Empire, and began crafting bronze cannons capable of lobbing 1.6 tons of shaped stone more than a mile.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE] Transporting such massive weapons took as many as 60 oxen, and required construction of entire road networks before the cannons could be brought to bear against the impregnable Theodosian Walls. Within a day of the opening bombardment, massive stones smashed the outer defenses to rubble and the city which had stood as a fortress of Christendom for a millennium fell. The sack of Constantinople raged for three days following, and triggered a mass exodus of Greeks into Europe proper. The influx of Byzantine refugees brought a rediscovery of the philosophical and intellectual achievements of Greek culture into Western Europe, planting the seeds of the Renaissance.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE] Stone bombards were supplanted by iron-ball cannons by the end of the 16th century, and few bombards are left intact. None of the bombard’s descendants, however, can claim to have single-handedly ended an era.
Goedendag

A cheap, versatile Defensive unit with supporting abilities. Only the Dutch may build it. Provides a combat boost to all Units adjacent to it and has increased [ICON_STRENGTH] Combat Strength if Garrisoned in a City.

The Goedendag is an odd unit, but effective in groups. While effective on their own against cavalry, the Goedendag provides increased attack against all units adjacent to it, and has additional combat strength if Garrisoned in a City at the beginning of your turn. Goedendag's do not boost their own combat strength, so Goedendags must be adjacent to each other to receive the benefit of their own promotion. These units can be built very quickly, so an army can be raised in the event of a surprise war.

A Goedendag is a four-foot long club with a spearhead at its tip that was used by the militias of Medieval Flanders during the Franco-Flemish War. The weapon was christened "goedendag" by the French, a cognate with the Dutch greeting "good day". This name may be a reference to the Bruges Matins massacre of 1302, in which the guildsmen of Bruges took over the city by greeting people in the streets and murdering anyone who answered with a French accent.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE] Goedendags were used to great effect by the guildsmen of Flanders against the French knights, but exactly how the weapon was used is a source of debate. Contemporary illustrations show it being used as a club, written accounts describe its first use as a spear to meet a charge, then a club as the enemy was halted. However they worked, men armed with Goedendags marked the beginning of the end for heavy cavalry in Western Europe, and the dawn of an "Infantry Revolution" where peasant militia were now a credible threat to professional soldiers. The stunning victory of common men over foreign tyrants became a wellspring of romantic nationalism for the Low Countries.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE] "each held his godendart (sic) raised against the French, the iron as one meets a wild boar"[NEWLINE]- Guillaume Guiart, a contemporary account describing the battle of Courtrai, 1302 A.D.

Hashemite Raider

Long considered the "Sick Man of Europe", Ottoman power was in decline well before nationalist sentiment took root in the Arab population. When WWI broke out among the European powers the Ottomans set about crushing Arab dissent. Arab citizens responded in a popular revolt, declaring a new Islamic empire.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE] Hussein bin Ali, Sharif of Mecca, began the rebellion in hopes of re-establishing a Hashemite dynasty in Arabia, and led his fellow Arabs in armed rebellion against their Turkish masters in Hejaz. Seeing an opportunity to tie down Ottoman forces in a new front, the British promised to recognize Arab hegemony and heavily subsidize the revolt, sending the now famous T.E. Lawrence as a liaison. With this new infusion of funds and equipment, the Arabs waged a guerilla war through the desert, crippling Ottoman supply lines. With the help of French and English navy, they were able to take several ports along the Mediterranean coast, emboldening even more to join their cause.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE] With the end of WWI in 1918 and the Ottomans’ defeat, the Arabs expected the full cooperation of their European allies as they established their new kingdom. However, the English and French had other plans. Behind closed doors, the French and English secretly formed the Sykes-Picot Agreement which divided the Middle-East amongst their own respective spheres of influence. This gross betrayal of a trusted ally has soured relations between the Arab states and the West ever since.

The Hashemite Raider the Arab replacement for the Light Tank. It is adept at hit-and-run tactics and disrupting enemy supply lines. Whenever it pillages an improvement, adjacent enemy units take 10 damage. Moves quickly through desert.

Fast and dangerous Modern Era Cavalry Unit. Only Arabia may build it. Available earlier, and does not require [ICON_RES_ALUMINUM] Aluminum. Moves faster and is stronger in Desert. Does not require [ICON_MOVES] Movement to pillage Tile Improvements, and deals damage to adjacent Enemy Units whenever it Pillages a tile.

The Hippodrome is the Byzantine Unique Wonder, replacing the Circus Maximus. In comparison to the Circus Maximus, The Hippodrome greatly increases Gold and Culture yields during "We Love the King Days" and begins a "We Love the King Day" on completion. All Arenas in the empire receive gold, while circuses receive Culture, and Horses get both.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE] Be careful to time when your transition into a new era comes. A turn of resistance could is a small price to pay for a free "We Love the King Day", but it could slow down a crucial wonder or come during a war.

Hippodromes were a chariot racing tracks and the beating heart of Byzantine social and political life. Though slightly smaller in footprint than the Circus Maximus in Rome, there was no equal to the Hippodrome of Constantinople's grandeur, adorned with art and treasures from all corners of the empire. The Constantinople Hippodrome was built by Constantine himself shortly after he moved his capital to the city. The track was placed adjacent to the palace, taking the shape of a massive 'U', with ten monuments lining its center.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE] Not just a pastime of the rich, the chariot races became the one place where the common people could see and interact with the emperor in a single venue. Commoners took the opportunity to begin chants for political or religious reforms during sporting events. Four political parties, or demes, existed within Constantinople which each sponsored a different racing team: The Blues, the Whites, the Greens and the Reds. Enormous sums of money were wagered on the outcomes of these races, which became further heated by the religious, societal, and political leanings which each team came to represent. One such feud in particular would come to overshadow them all: the Nika riots.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE] During the reign of Justinian I (an ardent supporter of the Blues), a dispute arose concerning the conviction of two hooligans, arrested for murder from a prior riot. The sentencing of these men unified the Blues and the Greens against Justinian in a terrible mob, and disgruntled nobles seized the opportunity to try to depose him as revenge for Justinian’s new taxes. Though at first he considered fleeing, Justinian rallied his loyal generals to corral the rioters into the Hippodrome, where they were butchered by royal guardsmen and Gothic mercenaries. By the time the Nika riots had ended, half of Constantinople had been burned down and 30,000 people were killed -- the deadliest riot in world history.
Huey Teocalli

In the Aztec Empire, a teocalli was a terraced pyramid surmounted by a roofed temple, and acted as the site of all the important religious rituals in the town. The greatest of these teocalli was located in the heart of Tenochtitlan, the Huey Teocalli (or, according to the Spanish, the Templo Mayor) dedicated to a pair of gods: Huitzilopochtli, the god of war, and Tlaloc, the god of agriculture (an indication of what was important in Aztec culture). Each god had a separate temple, reached by separate staircases.

The Huey Teocalli is the unique Aztec replacement for the Grand Temple. It does not require a Temple, and immediately triggers a Golden Age on completion. Every time you enter a Golden Age the Huey Teocalli permanently gains Food, Faith, and additional XP to units built in the city.

Does not require a Temple. Triggers a [ICON_GOLDEN_AGE] Golden Age on Completion.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]+2 [ICON_PEACE] Faith and +2 [ICON_CULTURE] Culture to all Temples, and +2 [ICON_FOOD] Food to all Barracks on Empire. Contains 1 slot for [ICON_GREAT_WORK] Great Work of Music. -1 [ICON_HAPPINESS_3] Unhappiness from [ICON_PEACE] Religious Unrest. Iron Chariot

Before horses were bred to be big enough to carry men on their backs, Assyrian chariots were used to smash into and disperse enemy formations. These sturdy chariots were both a platform for archers and javelins throwers and weapons themselves, forming the first shock tactics of history. Recognizing the great value of horses as weapons of war, Assyria was known for choosing lands to conquer specifically for their esteemed horse lineages.

Assyria's Iron Chariots act as shock troops to control the battlefield. They excel at breaking enemy ranks. The Iron Chariot gains a combat bonus for every adjacent enemy unit, neutralizing the enemy's flanking bonuses and allowing your chariots to take greater risks on the battlefield. Iron and Horse resources in excess of the number of Iron Chariots you own increase the combat effectivness of your chariots.

Durable shock cavalry of the Ancient Era. Only Assyria may build it. Ends turn if entering Rough Terrain.

May construct a Citadel. +15% Combat bonus to all Land units within 2 tiles.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]A unit stacked with an InDuna receives +50% Experience.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Expending an InDuna gives 30XP to the unit that was stacked with it, and deals 30 damage adjacent enemy units.

This Zulu Unique Great Person replaces the Great General. Aside from the ability to boost nearby troops and construct Citadels, Units stacked with an InDuna gain bonus Experience more quickly. Expending an InDuna gives bonus XP to a Stacked Unit, and immediately deals 30 damage to adjacent Enemy Units.

Leadership was not a complicated affair for the Zulu military. An inDuna guided each regiment, or 'ibutho', and he in turn answered to senior izinDuna who controlled the corps. One or more of these elder chiefs might accompany a big force on an important mission, but there was no single "field marshal" in command of all Zulu forces. Regimental izinDuna, like the non-commissioned officers of today's army, were important for morale and discipline. This was demonstrated during the battle of Isandlwana, where the army led by Ntshingwayo kaMahole outmaneuvered and destroyed a British column. Ntshingwayo kaMahole and his fellow izinDuna snuck a Zulu force of 20 000 men behind the British, hiding them in a valley only 7 miles from the British camp. When discovered sitting in complete silence by scouts, the izinDuna spurred their men into action and closed the remaining distance with lightning speed.

Iziko

An Iziko is a simple hearth used as a gathering place for Zulu communities. The fireplace was revered as a source for food, warmth, dreams, and ancestral ties. It is from these gatherings that a sense of community and identity was formed, and young Zulus could perform and bond.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE] The fireplace is used metaphorically for the "cooking of songs" in isicathamiya stage performances, a modern offshoot of traditional Zulu music. Dreams were an essential part of communicating with ancestors and formed part of a deeply rooted Zulu religion. Some isicathamiya musicians claim some of their songs were created in the spiritual realm or given to them by their ancestors.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE] "A person is a person because of other people"[NEWLINE]-Zulu proverb

Kabuki Theater

Kabuki is a classical Japanese dance-drama known for the stylization of its drama and for the elaborate make-up worn by some of its performers. The art form was created in 1603 when Izumo no Okuni, a miko of Izumo-taisha, began performing a new style of dance drama in the dry riverbeds of Kyoto. Despite many the upheaval of Japans modernization, Kabuki remains the most popular of the traditional styles of Japanese drama, and has helped renew interest in other forms of traditional Japanese art.
The Kabuki is the unique Japanese replacement for the Opera House. On construction, Any guilds in the city are replaced with unique Japanese guilds.

Does not require an Amphitheater in the City. +33% [ICON_GREAT_MUSICIAN] Great Musician Rate. All Musicians' Guilds produce +1 [ICON_GOLD] Gold. Monogatari Guild

Monogatari are a classical form of Japanses literature which gained popularity during the 10th century Heian period. Monogatari were traditionally epics and semi-religious tales, but later works included secular stories of courtly life, including Genji Monogatari, widely regarded as the first novel. Many of the most prolific and successful writers of Monogatari were noble women.

The Monogatari Guild is the unique Japanese replacement for the Writers' Guild. It generates Great Writers more quickly than the Writers' Guild, gives Gold for Writer specialists in the City, and provides Culture and Gold whenever a Great Artist is born on Empire.

Generates [ICON_GREAT_WRITER] Great Writers, and contains slots for Writer Specialists. 1 Specialist in this City no longer produces [ICON_HAPPINESS_3] Unhappiness from Urbanization.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]+2 [ICON_GOLD] Gold to Writer specialists in this city. When a [COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]Great Musician[ENDCOLOR] is born, Gain [ICON_CULTURE] Culture and [ICON_GOLD] Gold equal to 3% of the writer's potential [ICON_CULTURE] Culture from a [COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]Political Treatise[ENDCOLOR].
Ukiyo-e Guild

Ukiyo-e is a style of Japanese painting on woodblocks which flourished in the 17th century. The production of ukiyo-e was a collaborative affair, often with a separate painter who crafted the designs, a woodcarver who crafted the woodblock, and a printer who inked and reproduced the artwork. The striking angles, shapes and colours of Ukiyo-e would leave a lasting impression on Western art, informing the impressionist and modernist movements.

The Ukiyo-e Guild is the unique Japanese replacement for the Artists' Guild. It generates Great Artists more quickly than the Artists' Guild, gives Science for Artist specialists in the City, and provides Science and Golden Age Points whenever a Great Artist is born on Empire.

Generates [ICON_GREAT_ARTIST] Great Artists, and contains slots for Artist Specialists. 1 Specialist in this City no longer produces [ICON_HAPPINESS_3] Unhappiness from Urbanization.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]+2 [ICON_RESEARCH] Science to Artist specialists in this city. When a [COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]Great Artist[ENDCOLOR] is born, gain [ICON_RESEARCH] Science and [ICON_GOLDEN_AGE] Golden Age Points equal to 3% of the artist's potential [ICON_GOLDEN_AGE] Golden Age Points from [COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]Starting a Golden Age[ENDCOLOR].
Gagaku Guild

Gagaku is the oldest existing form of orchestral music in the world. The style was brought in from mainland China in the 6th century, and reached its peak in the 10th century's imperial court. Modern ensembles consist of three wind instruments, three percussion instruments, and a supporting string instrument.

The Gagaku Guild is the unique Japanese replacement for the Musicians' Guild. It generates Great Musicians more quickly than the Musicians' Guild, gives Faith for Musician and Civil Servant specialists in the City, and provides Tourism and Faith whenever a Great Artist is born on Empire.

Generates [ICON_GREAT_MUSICIAN] Great Musicians, and contains slots for Musician Specialists. 1 Specialist in this City no longer produces [ICON_HAPPINESS_3] Unhappiness from Urbanization.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]+2 [ICON_PEACE] Faith to Musician specialists in this city. When a [COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]Great Musician[ENDCOLOR] is born, Gain 200 [ICON_TOURISM] Tourism and [ICON_PEACE] Faith equal to 3% of the musician's potential [ICON_TOURISM] Tourism from a [COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]Concert Tour[ENDCOLOR].
Kampong

The term ‘Sama-Bajau’ refers to a single ethnic group scattered between the modern day Philippines, Indonesia, and Malaysia. The Sama people live a semi-sedentary life in stilt villages or “kampongs” in coastal shallows, while Bajau refers to nomadic groups living in house boats. The Sama-Bajau defy national and ethnic borders, travelling and fishing between islands on the open ocean. In addition to their cultural and ethnic distinctiveness, the Bajau-Laut boast physical adaptations to their semi-aquatic way of life. Bajau-Laut possess unique abilities which allow them to see better underwater, and dive longer and deeper than any other group of humans.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]In recent years, the Bajau-Laut have been forced into sedentary lifestyles by various governments, and face discrimination as pagans, outsiders and squatters. A combination of overfishing and modernization threatens the Bajau’s nomadic traditions, as they have been forcibly resettled on land. Still, a few communities of Bajau-Laut ride their lepa lepa across the blue water of Southeast Asia, only traveling to shore a few times each year.

The Kampong can be built by [ICON_WORKER] Embarked Workers on Coastal and Lake Tiles, and not next to another Kampong.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Each Kampong yields [ICON_FOOD] Food and [ICON_CULTURE] Culture, and adjacent Fishing Boats receive +1 [ICON_PRODUCTION] Production.

Khopesh

Khopesh is the Egyptian name of the Canaanite "sickle-sword", designed for hooking an opponent's shield or disarming them. The weapon evolved from the epsilon axes that were common in warfare at the time. Note, however, that the khopesh is not an axe, but rather a slashing weapon like a sabre. Its origins can be traced back to Sumer of the third millennium BC, where the Stele of Vultures depicts Eannatum of Lagash, the world's first emperor, wielding a khopesh. Many of the histories of Egyptian Pharaohs depict them holding the weapon. Indeed, most examples of khopesh recovered from tombs do not show signs of ever having been sharpened, indicating their use as ceremonial, or status symbols.

The Khopesh is the unique Egyptian replacement for the Spearman. It's a strong early unit that has an edge in direct combat. However, unlike the Spearman it replaces, it does not have a combat bonus against mounted units.
Strong, front-line Unit of the Ancient Era. Only Egypt may build it. Deals increased damage against heavily damaged Units. Does not have a bonus against Mounted Units.

Front-line Unit which grows more powerful with experience. Only Babylon may build it. This unit is stronger than the Spearman it replaces. Receives additional [ICON_STRENGTH] Combat Strength for every few levels and gains more XP from fights.

A soldier to stand the test of time. The Kibitum is not the strongest unit in its era, but its true strength lies in how it gains more power from experience than normal units. Keep these soldiers alive, and they will form an indispensable core for your army.

The Babylonians were descended from semi-nomadic Amorite and Akkadian tribes from upper Mesopotamia. With the collapse of the Sumerian and Akkadian kingdoms, these Amorite tribes poured into Mesopotamia unopposed and established new dynasties. While in many respects these conquerors assimilated into Sumerian culture, their armies retained the toughness of their nomadic roots.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE] The Sabum Kibitum were the heavy troops of the Babylonians and one of the earliest examples of career soldiers in history. Assembled from the royal guard and city residents, Sabum Kibitum were armed with long and short spears, javelins and bows to form a disciplined and flexible fighting force.

Klepht

A quick and elusive guerilla fighter. Only Greece may build it. Slightly weaker than the Gatling Gun it replaces and does not have the [COLOR_RED]Covering Fire I[ENDCOLOR] Promotion. Starts with the [COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]Philhellenism[ENDCOLOR] and [COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]Altitude Training[ENDCOLOR] Promotions, and can move after attacking.

The Klepht is not as powerful as the Gatling Gun it replaces, but can move quickly through hills, even after attacking. This unit also gains gold and production for every city-state ally every time it attacks a unit.

Bandits and mountainfolk, turned anti-Ottoman insurgents and freedom fighters, The Klephts were the bedrock upon which the modern Greek army was formed. Together with the men originally hired to capture them, the Armatoloi, the Klephts formed the "yeast of liberty", and the first hope for Greek independence after more than four centuries of Ottoman rule.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE] Undisciplined and flighty as one would expect of brigands, Klephts waged an effective guerilla campaign against the much larger Ottoman armies sent to subdue them. Massacres on both sides of the conflict were inflicted, but European sympathies fell heavily in favor of the Greeks. The unbridled cruelty of the Muslim Ottomans outraged Europe’s citizenry, who raised supplies, food and even soldiers to fight for a Hellenic independence.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE] After 8 years Ottoman forces had finally managed to crush the revolt, but where Greek soldiers had failed poets and propaganda had succeeded. French, British and Russian governments each sent a fleet in defense of the Greek islands, in response to popular demand for intervention. In the face of such overwhelming force, the Ottomans sued for peace and liberated Greece. After more than 2,000 years under the boots of Macedonian, Roman and Ottoman conquerors, The Greek homeland was at last free -- unified as one people for the first time in history.
Kapu Ku'ialua

Both a strong scout and front-line Unit. Only Polynesia may build it. Slightly stronger than the Scout it replaces, and starts with the [COLOR_GREEN]Amphibious[ENDCOLOR] Promotion.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Inflicts Leiomano status on enemies during melee combat, reducing Max HP by 20 and reducing Healing by 10 for 2 turns.

The Koa is an effective early scout, able to hold its own against barbarians. It is stronger than the Scout, and can fight equally well across rivers and while embarked. This unit also inflicts Max HP and healing reduction to enemies it attacks for 2 turns, making them effective at clearing barbarians and preventing healing.

Deadly warriors from the islands of Hawai'i, Koa are named after the koa tree from which most of their weapons were fashioned. These warriors were trained extensively in Kapu Ku'ialua, a traditional Hawai'ian martial art specializing in weaponry and the focusing of mana into bone-shattering attacks.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]In battle, Koa warriors were well-versed in many weapons, including the less conventional knuckle-dusters, slings, and garrotes, but were also capable hand-to-hand fighters. More conventional daggers and clubs would occasionally be fitted with shark teeth along their edges, creating devastating serrated weapons called 'Leiomano'. These weapons were used similarly to the obsidian-tipped Macuahuitl of Central America.

The Laguna is a Medieval-era building, replacing the Harbor. It improves the range and [ICON_GOLD] Gold yield of sea trade routes, and boosts the value of sea tiles and resources. The Laguna also increases the [ICON_PRODUCTION] Production of Naval units by 15%, and increases Military Units supplied by this City''s population by 10%. The Laguna additionally provide bonus yields to Murano Glassworks, Rialto District, and Arsenale di Venezia.

Laguna (eng. Lagoons) are shallow bodies of salt water separated from a larger sea by barrier islands or reefs. Venice itself is situated on the bank of a large lagoon, artificially maintained and enlarged by the dredging of the Venetian canals. The Venice Lagoon is also the largest wetland in the Mediterranean, offering protection as well as a rich source of food to its inhabitants.
Lamassu Gate

Lamassu are Assyrian protective deities, often depicted as having a human head, the body of a bull or lion, and bird's wings. The Lamassu were household protective spirits of Babylonian and Assyrian commoners, and were later adopted as royal protectors. Depictions of Lamassu are found throughout Assyrian architecture, positioned as sentinels at the thresholds of buildings and as colossal statues on each side of the city and palace gates. Common folk, for their part, engraved Lamassi onto clay tablets and buried them under their door's threshold.

Unique Wall replacement. Military Units supplied by this City's population increases by 20% and Increases the City's [ICON_RANGE_STRENGTH] Bombard Strength by 25%. Contains a Writer specialist slot and a Great Work of Writing slot to help your empire get an early start on great works.

[ICON_WAR] Military Supplies by this City's population increased by 20%. Increases the City's [ICON_RANGE_STRENGTH] Bombard Strength by 10% and Strike Range by 1. Landwehr

The Austro-Hungarian Dual Monarchy sponsored two separate land armies to defend its Austrian and Hungarian portions. The Kaiserlich-Königliche Landwehr were one of three (or maybe six?) components of the Austrian national defense force between 1868 and 1918, the Austrian counterpart to the Hungarian Honved. Ludwig van Beethoven himself was commissioned to write the marching song for the Bohemian division, now famously known as the Yorkscher Marsch.[NEWLINE[NEWLINE] While the Hungarian Honved was generously supported by their parliament in Budapest, legislators in Vienna generally failed to do the same for the Landwehr, leaving it a skeletal force with only the appearance of parity. Nationalist interests led to a gradual strengthening and improvement of the Landwehr leading up to the First World War, just in time to see the entire Austro-Hungarian Empire collapse for good.

The Landwehr is the backbone of the Industrial-era Austrian army. It excels in defending in owned territory and the territory of allied city-states. Each Landwehr can in the empire can also act as a passive source of culture if garrisoned in a city, fort or citadel.

Stalwart defensive Unit. Only Austria may build it. Has additional [ICON_STRENGTH] Combat Bonus when fighting in Territory owned by you or Allied City-States. Longship

Early Naval Exploration Unit. Only Denmark may build it. Available earlier, can move after attacking, and has [COLOR_GREEN]Blockade[ENDCOLOR] Promotion. Embarked Civilian Units starting their turn on the same tile as a longship may enter deep Ocean.

The Danish Longship is an early ship unit which allow Denmark to have early sea control. This allows Denmark to begin scouting the far seas earlier than the other players to prepare future waves of colonization, defend your colonies abroad and provides support to raids with its bonuses to city attack at sea and performing hit-and-run tactics.

Longships were a type of boat invented and used by the Norsemen for trade, exploration, and warfare during the Viking Age. The longship's design evolved over many centuries, beginning in the Stone Age with the invention of the umiak and continuing up until the 6th century with clinker-built ships like Nydam and Kvalsund, appearing in its complete form between the 9th and 13th centuries. They were all made out of wood, with woven wool sails, and had numerous details and carvings on the hull. [NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Longships were notable for their quick speed and light construction. The ships were sturdy and reliable at sea, yet light enough to be carried onto shore or even tipped over as a makeshift shelter. The ability to move quickly in and out of shore was invaluable during the Vikings’ infamous raids. [NEWLINE][NEWLINE]The character and appearance of these ships are still reflected in Scandinavian boat-building traditions. Skills and methods for making longships are still used worldwide, often with modern adaptations

An ancient precursor to today’s agribusinesses, A Latifundium was an expansive privately owned farm specializing in intensive agriculture. The first latifundia were accumulated from the spoils of war, confiscated from conquered peoples beginning in the early 2nd century BC in Magna Graecia (Southern Italy). The Latifundia system later expanded with conquest, to the Roman provinces of the Maghreb and Hispania Baetica in southern Spain [NEWLINE][NEWLINE]These estates depended on forced labor for their productivity, often supplied by the enslavement of the very peoples whose land had been taken. The Latifundia consolidated into larger estates with greater economies of scale. Owners re-invested their profits by purchasing small neighbouring farms. Evicted from their farms and replaced by slave labour, the Roman peasantry were forced to find work in the cities of Rome, though often resorting to squatting and handouts. [NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Latifundia became the template upon which later European nations would base their imperial experiments. The Spanish are especially noteworthy for patterning the Encomienda system after the late Roman Latifundia.

Licorne is a siege unit that can change the course of battle. Innovative construction allows moving after attacks and no penalty while attacking melee units. Is available earlier than the Field Gun.

Licorne is the French name given to the Russian 'unicorn' cannons, named for the distinctively shaped handles on the gun barrels. Devised in 1757, Licornes were a flexible design, easy to fire and transport and made in many differing weights and power. Lighter designs are best remembered from their use as mobile horse artillery, a Russian innovation that would change the European theory of combined arms for the next century.

Madrasa

"Madrasa" is Arabic for any type of educational institution. Though often with a religious component, madrasas were primarily secular, and could cover anything from elementary to higher learning, including medicine, law, science, philosophy or the education of women. The first madrasa, the Gama'at al-Qarawiyyn, was established in 859 AD by Fatimah al-Fihri, the daughter of a wealthy merchant. During the rule of the Fatimid, Ayyubid and Mamluk dynasties, the practice of sponsoring madrasas by the ruling elite spread across Egypt and the Middle East. As Europe suffered through the Dark Ages, the madrasas of the Turks and Arabs would keep the best of Western knowledge alive, blending it with that of the East.
Unique Arabian replacement for the University. In addition to the bonuses of a University, the Madrasa generates additional yields when you purchase anything with Faith or expend a Great Person.

Monolithic Church

The term "Monolithic Church" (or "rock-hewn church") can be attributed to any church cut from a single stone formation, but is most often used to refer to the complex of 11 churches in Lalibela, Ethiopia. These churches were constructed in the 12th century by King Gebre Mesqel Lalibela, a devout Christian. This 'New Jerusalem' is situated in a mountainous region in the heart of Ethiopia, and is an important center of Christian pilgrimage to this day.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE] Monolithic Churches are found in places besides Lalibela, including many in Tigray. These churches were almost unknown to the outside world until Abba Tewelde Medhin Josief, a Catholic priest, announced the existence of over 120 rock-hewn churches, 90 of which were still in use. Over the next few years, the total of known churches was raised to 153.

Can be built on [ICON_RES_STONE] Stone or on Unfeatured Hills if not next to another Monolithic Church. An Oppidum is a large defended settlement associated with the late La Tene culture. These fortified villages were often built in naturally protected areas and full of circular constructions. In times of conflict, the people who lived in open fields moved to these strategically located compounds to ensure their safety. Oppida could also have other purposes such as control of territory or safeguarding of crops. The most famous oppidum was Alesia, the site of the battle between Julius Caesar and Vercingetorix and the final defeat of the Gauls, ending of Gallic independence in France and Belgium.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE] Oppidum improve the yields of adjacent improvements:[NEWLINE] [ICON_BULLET]+1 [ICON_FOOD] Food and +1 [ICON_PRODUCTION] Production to Farms[NEWLINE] [ICON_BULLET]+1 [ICON_FOOD] Food and +1 [ICON_PEACE] Faith to Camps[NEWLINE] [ICON_BULLET]+1 [ICON_PRODUCTION] Production and +1 [ICON_PEACE] Faith to Pastures[NEWLINE] [ICON_BULLET]+1 [ICON_PRODUCTION] Production and +1 [ICON_GOLD] Gold to Mines[NEWLINE] [ICON_BULLET]+1 [ICON_PRODUCTION] Production and +1 [ICON_RESEARCH] Science to Quarries[NEWLINE] [ICON_BULLET]+1 [ICON_GOLD] Gold and +1 [ICON_CULTURE] Culture to Plantations[NEWLINE] [ICON_BULLET]+1 [ICON_FOOD] Food and +1 [ICON_RESEARCH] Science to Lumbermills[NEWLINE] [ICON_BULLET]+1 [ICON_FOOD] Food and +1 [ICON_CULTURE] Culture to Logging Camps[NEWLINE] [ICON_BULLET]+1 [ICON_GOLD] Gold and +1 [ICON_PEACE] Faith to Fishing Boats

The Pairidaeza is the Persian unique Garden replacement. In addition to the normal bonuses of a Garden, each the Pairidaeza increases Gold production during Golden Ages. The beginning of every Golden Age produces culture for each city with a Pairidaeza, so be sure to build them in every city.

A Pairidaeza is a walled garden popularized by the Achaemenid. As a tool of state, Pairidaeza were invaluable in flaunting a kingdom’s ability to bring life to an area that would otherwise have none; its rectangular, ordered construction serving as a contrast the chaos of nature. The Achaemenid dynasty melded the pairidaeza with their royal hunting parks, an unsubtle way to show their command over both their empire and the natural world within it. The Persian gardens form the root of the greek “paradise”, informing western notions of an earthly Eden in art and poetry.

The Pitz Court is the Mayan unique building, replacing the Arena. In addition to the normal bonuses of an Arena, the Pitz Court provides Science and Faith at the end of every long count. Land units trained in a City with a Pitz Court receive the 'K'atun Ahaw' promotion, which grants new abilities for every 20 turns the unit has been alive. The Mesoamerican Ball Game, or 'Pitz', is a game of ritual and cultural significance among the Mayan people. The object of the game is to keep the ball in play for as long as possible by striking back and forth within a sloped arena using the hips, though some variations allowed for elbows, shoulders and even rackets. The earliest archaeological evidence of the game come from a court estimated to be 3400 years old.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE] Over 1300 different ballcourts have been found within Mayan ruins, with relatively little variation in size or layout over thousands of years. Every court is shaped as a narrow alley with gently sloping walls on either side and enclosed endzones. This gave the court a roughly H-shaped layout. Later versions of the ballcourts would include hoops at the midpoint, suspended on the walls. Actually sending a ball through the ring must have been a rare occurrence, since the players could not use their hands or feet to guide the ball. Moreover, the rings were only slightly larger than the ball itself and were a long way from the playing alley.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE] The game was more than a mere sporting event to the Mayan people, serving as a substitute for war in the case of a dispute between cities. Later Classical Mayan art suggests a link between the ball game and ritual sacrifice, with winners being decapitated as an offering to the gods. The Maya Twin Myth of the Popol Vuh describes the game between the Hero Twins, Hunahpu and Xbalanque, and lords of the underworld, One Death and Seven Death. The game was played so the Hero Twins might recover Hunahpu's head, which was being used as a ball by the Lords (Hunahpu had been using a squash for his head until his real one could be recovered).
Bogurodzica
