Pancerny

A sturdy Mounted Skirmisher. Only Poland may build it. Earns [ICON_PEACE] Faith from each Enemy killed and double the amount from Barbarians. This Unit is stronger in both defense and offense than the Heavy Skirmisher, and has additional protection against Ranged Units.

Pancerny is the Polish replacement for the Heavy Skirmisher. It has stronger attack and defense than the Heavy Skirmisher, and takes reduced damage from Ranged attacks. The Pancerny also earns Faith for each enemy killed. As mounted unit, the Pancerny is vulnerable to Pikemen.

Towarzysz Pancerny (Mailed Companion) was a rank of Polish cavalryman from the 10th to 18th century, named for their chainmail armor. Pancerni were organized into companies, with each company consisting of 60 to 200 horsemen. Exceptionally well-armored, they used chainmail or platemail armor, vambraces, helmets, and buckler shields. The most common armaments were sabres, reflex bows and, with the arrival of gunpowder, flintlock pistols and carbines.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE] After the rise of heavy cavalry the Pancerni often worked in concert with the newer and more heavily armed husaria, augmenting a cavalry charge and chasing down routing enemy soldiers. By the second half of the 17th century, they represented approximately 70% of all soldiers in the Polish military, fighting against Cossacks, Tatars, and the Swedish. The Husaria and Pancerni were eventually combined to form the ‘Kawaleria Narodowa’, the Polish-Lithuanian National Cavalry.

Unique Russian replacement for the Customs House. Initially, Pogosts are comparatively lackluster, but they develop new traits as the game progresses. Each stage increases Gold generated from City Connections, and The Pogost provides modest increases in gold from trade and culture, then gains modest boosts to gold and science at its second stage, and provides boosts to faith generation in its final stage.

In many medieval Russian states, Pogosts began as inns and lodging for the nobility and priesthood, but may have doubled as community centers and trading hubs. By the end of the 10th century, however, Pogosts had evolved into administrative and legislative hubs throughout the Slavic states. By 1775 the last Pogost-led administrative district was abolished, and the buildings were repurposed as parishes of the Eastern Orthodox Church.

Prau

One of the most ancient of seaworthy boat designs, the prau, also known as proa or perahu, are wooden sailing vessels consisting of a large hull (vaka) and a small hull (ama) set in parallel by a crossbeam (akas). Prau are believed to have been developed in Micronesia in the first century AD, spreading quickly throughout southeast Asia. Western accounts of prau first appear in the 16th century, when Magellan made note of their agility in his fateful trip to the Philippines.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]When sailing in strong winds, the crew walk between the hulls along the akas to counterbalance the force of the sail. A skilled prau crew can balance so as to lift the ama out of the water, called "flying the ama", and skim the ocean's surface to reach incredible speeds. Prau continue to be used worldwide, and modern designs can exceed 95km/h in favourable winds. This makes prau some of the fastest ships in the world; not bad for a 2,000 year old!
The Prau is faster and cheaper than the Trireme it replaces and ignores zone of control. It is great for early game scouting and raiding.
Effective early Naval Scout. Only Indonesia may build it. This unit is faster and available earlier than the Trireme it replaces. Starts with the [COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]Pincer[ENDCOLOR] Promotion.
Penteconter
Dominant Classical Era Naval Unit used to own the seas well into the Medieval Era with its ranged attack.
The first naval unit with a ranged attack. It cannot end its turn in Deep Ocean tiles outside of the city borders.

The penteconter was an ancient Greek Galley, used for trade, piracy and warfare. The ship was rowed by 50 oarsmen arranged in 2 rows of 25, making the ship long, but relatively narrow. This design made the boat relatively quick, but difficult to turn during a naval engagement.

A nimble attacker excelling in Rough Terrain. Only the Iroquois may build it. Cheaper than the Musketman, this Unit can attack from behind obstacles and withdraw from enemy attacks.

The Prowler is a cheap unit that makes perfect use of surrounding rough terrain. The Prowler's "Indirect Fire" promotion allows him to attack unseen from deep forests and hills, with the aid of reconnaissance or friendly borders. When attacked by an enemy unit, he can withdraw from combat. The prowler's evasiveness makes him an ideal guerilla Unit.

Unlike many other tribes, the Iroquois had easy access to trade goods at Dutch forts along the Hudson River, and traded for various goods and luxuries. Weapons of war such as the iron axe and musket were highly sought after, and by the 1640s the Iroquois were well-equipped to fight their traditional Huron and Algonquian enemies. Common muskets were given in exchange for pelts and food, but often of lighter and smaller caliber than military-grade muskets. The Dutch and British feared giving high-quality weapons to people who could turn against them, but the Iroquois often found the smaller weapons more suitable to rough terrain anyways.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE] War tactics were changed after the Iroquois' acquisition of firearms. The lethality of their new weapons put the Iroquois, never a highly populous group, in a precarious position. The tribes' custom of absorbing refugees and prisoners of war changed as fewer and fewer warriors survived clashes with European arms. Great armies walking with prominent chiefs and shamans were replaced with guerilla tactics, small bands of troops guided by commanders.

The Gumey is a Songhai unique building that replaces the Caravansary. The Gumey provides much larger bonuses to trade than the normal Caravansary, boosting International Trade Routes, and extra yields if a trade route passes through the city. Expand your empire's territory and reap the economic benefits of a vast trade empire.

Even before gaining their independence from the Mali Empire, the Songhai had become ludicrously wealthy off the trade of gold, salt and slaves from the Trans-Saharan trade routes. The Songhai's seat of power lay at the edge of the vast Saharan desert, forming an entrepot between the Taghazan salt mines to the north, the gold mines in the southwest, and the distant markets in Egypt and the Middle East. The Gumey were riverside ports and waystations, used to conduct goods and soldiers back and forth along the Niger river, before they were loaded onto camels for the arduous journey across the open desert.

Potent Mid-game cavalry focused on economic warfare. Only Persia may build it. Can always be purchased with [ICON_PEACE] Faith.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Generates [ICON_PEACE] Faith, [ICON_GOLD] Gold, and [ICON_GOLDEN_AGE] Golden Age Points when pillaging tiles.

The Qizilbash is the Unique Persian replacement for the Lancer. Stronger than the Lancer, the Qizilbash also generates Faith, Gold and Golden Age Points for every tile they pillage. This unit can also be purchased with Faith without needing a religious tenet. Maintaining a strong presence in enemy territory allows Persia to generate Faith for more Qizilbash, and trigger more Golden Ages to increase your army's power.

Qizilbash (Tr: “red-heads”) was originally a pejorative for the followers of the Safawiyyah Sufi order. Named for their distinctive crimson headwear, the Qizilbash organized into a Shi'ite society reminiscent of a European knightly order. Though primarily of Turkman origin, the Qizilbash proved instrumental in the establishment of the Iranian Safavid Dynasty.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE] In a campaign to avenge the death of his father, Ismail I led 7000 Qizilbash warriors to victory over an Aq Qoyunlu force of 30 000, and established the Safavid State. Within eleven short years, Ismail brought all of Iran under his control, becoming the first ethnically Iranian monarch to unify Iran in over 850 years. Though they had made him a powerful king, Ismail feared the influence of the Qizilbash over the Iranian people. Ismail and his successors would spend the next 80 years diminishing the threat posed by the foreign Qizilbash, replacing them with slave soldiers from the Caucasus. Nevertheless, the Qizilbash maintained a place of honor within the Safavid Empire, both on the battlefield and at court.
Qila

The Qila is the unique Indian replacement for the Castle. In addition to the normal bonuses of the Castle, the Qila generates Culture and Great Artist Points. 10% of City Defense is converted into Culture every turn and the city gains more defense for wonders built in the city. Your most magnificent cities also become more difficult to capture.

The Mughals were an Islamic empire that invaded India in the 15th century, and ruled most of the sub-continent until the mid 19th. During their rule, they constructed elaborate forts called Qila across the countryside which served as administrative centers and living quarters for the occupiers. These forts were beautiful structures, fitting palaces for the rulers of a vast empire. Several--including the magnificent "Lahore Fort" and Red Fort of Agra--survive today and remain as some of the largest tourist attractions to India, monuments to the Mughals' power and style.
Homestead

A Homestead is a complex of buildings on a large landholding, typically a ranch, settled in accordance with the United States Homesteading Acts. The US Government implemented a policy of "free soil", allowing claimants, effectively squatters, ownership of land which they had converted into productive farms or ranches. Nearly 10% of the continental United States was settled in this way; 270 million acres of land claimed by approximately 1.6 million homesteaders between 1862 and 1930.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]The colonization of vast swathes of the continental interior left an indelible mark on the American psyche. Legends of the frontier, the Old West, Cowboys and Indians still permeate American culture, informing their sense of independence, enterprising spirit and mastery over nature.

The Homestead is the American replacement for the Stable. In addition to the regular abilities of the Stable, the Homestead immediately claims all Sheep, Horse, Cattle and Bison resources around the City. The production bonus for each claimed tile can help refund a bit of the cost of the Homestead immediately. The Homestead boosts Bison in addition to all the resources normally boosted by a Ranch, and all boosted resources gain additional food.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]The Homestead boosts the production of workers and settler units, and allows America to train Pioneers a full era before they usually unlock. With the Homestead, America can settle new, powerful cities quickly.

Riad

A Riad is a traditional Moroccan house with an interior garden or courtyard. The riads were often plain on the exterior, but lavishly decorated inside, projecting humility and austerity while preserving a family’s privacy. The interior gardens often featured elaborate fountains and tiling, while the walls were adorned with quotes from the Quran in Arabic calligraphy.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE] While architectural style has changed over the years, the riad’s basic form is still used in modern design. Riads have enjoyed a renaissance, with restoration efforts of old, often crumbling buildings in Marrakech and Essaouira. Many riads are now repurposed as hotels or restaurants.

The Riad is the Moroccan unique replacement for the Garden. Gold purchases in this city are slightly cheaper. Gold generation in the city is converted into [ICON_GREAT_PEOPLE] Great Merchant Points. Oases are boosted by the Riad more than by a normal Garden. Unlike other buildings, the Riad's base yields increase with each Era.

Unique Iroquoian replacement for the Scrivener's Office. In addition to the normal bonuses provided by the Scrivener's Office, the Sachem's Council provides faster generation of Great Diplomat units. Great Diplomats also receive a unique promotion, providing Science, Culture and gold for every embassy founded. All Councils in your empire also gain +1 Culture, and all Chanceries gain +2 Gold. The Sachem's Council also provides Happiness for every Defensive Pact and Declared War involving the Iroquois.

According to oral tradition, the five tribes of the Iroquois devoted much energy toward fighting and killing each other until the 1500s. It was at this time that the five tribes united into a powerful confederation, forming an elaborate political system including a bicameral (two-house) legislature.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE] In accordance with their unwritten constitution, the confederacy was represented by 50 delegates, or Sachems -- male representatives of the tribes, hand-picked by their respective clan mother. The 17 sachems from the Seneca and Mohawk tribes met in one house while the 19 Oneida and Cayuga met in the other. The 14 Onondaga sachems acted as tie-breakers and had the power to veto decisions made by the others. In addition to Sachem, who met on Onondaga land to cast their votes, an advisory council was formed, called the Pine Trees. Pine Trees could be men or women appointed for their heroic feats and accomplishments. In 1715 the Tuscarora joined the league, and it was renamed the League of Six Nations. Benjamin Franklin’s dealings with the Iroquois left an impression on him, and led him to model the United States’ government after theirs.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE] “The soil of the earth from one end of the land to the other is the property of the people who inhabit it. By birthright the Ongwehonweh (original beings) are the owners of the soil which they own and occupy and none other may hold it. The same law has been held from the oldest times. The Great Creator has made us of the one blood and of the same soil he made us and as only different tongues constitute different nations he established different hunting grounds and territories and made boundary lines between them...” [NEWLINE] -Excerpt from the Iroquois Constitution
Sambadrome

A Sambadrome is an exhibition place for the Samba schools parades during Carnaval in Brazil. A Sambadrome generally consists of tiered spectator viewing areas surrounding a long alley for the schools to parade down. The parades attract many thousands of Brazilians and foreign tourists each year.

The Sambadrome is the unique Brazilian replacement for the Opera House. In addition to the bonuses of an Opera House, the Sambadrome also generates Golden Age Points. The Sambadrome comes with a Musician specialist slot, and all Musicians in the city generate extra Gold and Golden Age Points.

Scythed Chariot
A dangerous Unit on Open Terrain. Only the Celts may build it. This unit is stronger against Archer and Melee Units.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]After moving, deals damage to all newly adjacent Enemy Units.

The Scythed Chariot is a Celtic unique unit made for destroying enemy lines. Enemies take damage whenever the Scythed Chariot moves adjacent to them, making this unit deadly in open terrain. Make every move count to maximize damage, but be careful not to leave your Chariots exposed to enemies on their turn. A mounted unit, the Scythed Chariot is vulnerable to Spearmen.

Scythed chariots are modified war chariots with long blades extending from the wheel axels. Though often dismissed as fanciful storytelling, the use of scythed chariots has been ascribed to Pictish, Irish and Iceni armies. The only report of a scythed chariot in Britain outside of Roman propaganda comes from the Irish Ulster Cycle, during the adventures of Chu Chulainn.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE] Although chariots had fallen out of use in continental Europe from the end of the 3rd century BC, Caesar found that they remained significant in British warfare. Caesar encountered both Celtic cavalry and chariots and described how these warriors would throw javelins from their vehicles before dismounting to fight on foot. Celtic soldiers could return to their chariots to quickly retreat or redeploy.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE] “They make war not only on horseback but also from two horse chariots and cars armed in the Gallic fashion – they call them Covinni - on which they use axles equipped with scythes.” [NEWLINE] - Pomponius Mela

Seir Morb

Industrial Era Unit specializing in coastal defense. Only Siam may build it. Has a bonus against Naval Units instead of a penalty. No bonuses against Cities.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Deals more damage on attack the less the Unit has moved. Starts with the [COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]Cover I[ENDCOLOR] and [COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]Cover II[ENDCOLOR] Promotions.

A powerful coastal defense cannon, the Seir Morb is more powerful than the Field Gun it replaces, especially against naval targets, but deals less damage to cities. The Seir Morb receives a combat boost for every remaining movement point when attacking, so pick a good spot and keep it steady. Location, Location, Location.

Despite Siam's remarkable diplomacy, they did occasionally come into conflict with the great imperial powers which threated their independence. When the French set their sights on Laos, the Siamese mistakenly believed the English would support them against France, and prepared for war. The Seir Morb ("Crouching Tiger") were the most technologically advanced cannons in the Siamese arsenal at the time; coastal artillery which could destroy any French boats foolish enough to enter their harbours. No amount of raw power, however, can account for corruption and disorganization; the French managed to establish their beachheads, and the coastal artillery of Thailand remained unused. It turns out that the finest artillery money can buy still needs to be fired.
Suffet

This Carthaginian unique Great Person replaces the Great General. Aside from the ability to boost nearby troops and construct citadels, this unit disembarks onto water tiles as a [ICON_GREAT_ADMIRAL] Great Admiral. Causes Friendly Units beginning in the same or adjacent tile to ignore Enemy Zone of Control for that turn.

The Suffet is the unique Great General and Great Admiral replacement for Carthage. This unit causes all friendly units beginning in the same or an adjacent tile to ignore an enemy's Zone of Control for that turn. In addition, whenever this unit embarks into a water tile, it becomes a Great Admiral. It returns to Great General status upon disembarking into a city. Use a Suffet to enhance your military's power and mobility in pitched battles.

In the various independent city-states and colonies of Phoenicia a Suffet (or Shophet) was a non-royal magistrate granted control over a city-state, sometimes functioning much in the same way as a Roman consul. Following the overthrow of its monarchy in the 5th century BC, Carthage was ruled by a number of aristocratic councils presided over by two suffets. The exceptional leadership of suffet generals like Hannibal Barca have become legendary, handing Rome the greatest defeats it had ever suffered.

Shofet

This Israelite unique Great Person replaces the Great General. Aside from the ability to boost nearby troops and construct citadels, this unit generates +2 [ICON_CULTURE] Culture and [ICON_PEACE] Faith every turn.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Deals damage every turn to enemy cities the Shofet is adjacent to. Damage is doubled if the city is [ICON_BLOCKADED] Blockaded

The Shofet is the unique Great General replacement for Israel. The Shofet is very effective at shortening sieges, dealing consistent damage each turn if adjacent to an enemy city. Shoftim also act as a steady supply of Faith and Culture for your Empire, so don't feel the need to build citadels with them right away.

The Judges of Israel, or Shoftim, were Israelite military leaders in times of crisis, before Israel established their monarchy. The Book of Judges in the Hebrew Bible describes the Shofet as part of a cyclical pattern: The Israelite people fall away from their god, hardship is brought on as punishment from God, the Israelites cry out to the Lord for rescue, God sends a Shofet to lead the Israelites to overthrow their persecutors, and the cycle repeats. The cycle of Judges is thought to have gone on for between 300 and 500 years.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]The first judge of Israel named by the Bible was Moses, who is said to have led the Israelites out of bondage in Egypt and established the Jewish law. After Moses, Joshua led the Israelites in the conquest of Canaan. The final judge named in the Bible was Samuel, who anointed both the first and second kings of the new Kingdom of Israel.

Shotelai

Front-line Medieval Era land Unit. Only Ethiopia may build it. It is stronger against Mounted Units, unlike the Longswordsman it replaces. Enemies attacked by this Unit have -2 [ICON_MOVES] Movement Points on their next turn.
Unique replacement for the Longswordsman. This unit specializes in combating Mounted opponents and hobbling retreating units. Only Ethiopia may build it.

Shotel are dramatically curved double-edged swords used exclusively by the ancient Ethiopian Empire’s Shotelai warriors. Almost semicircular, the shotel could be used to hook shields, or even reach around them to strike an opponent. The sword could also be used to hook and unhorse a mounted soldier, bringing them to the ground. Elite corps of Shotelai were employed by the armies of Amda Seyon I, comprising an elite force within his mighty host.
Ulfhedinn

The strength and ferocity of the tribal Germanic warriors was legendary among Roman writers and soldiers alike. Of particular note were the Ulfhedinn, Odin's sacred warriors who clothed themselves in wolf pelts and imitated wolves while fighting. Germanic tribesmen stood an average of 6 inches taller than a Latini, but were often overmatched by the Legions' superior equipment, organization, and training. German fortunes would change, however, under the leadership of Arminius.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE] A Cherusci commander who had spent time training under the Romans, Arminius organized a coalition of five German tribes to strike back at the Roman invaders under Publius Varus. The Germans falsified reports of a northern Germanic uprising and laid an ambush for Varus deep in the Teutoburg Forest. Using their superior numbers, heavy rain, and Arminius' knowledge of Roman tactics, the Roman’s defeat at Teutoburg Forest was thorough, with 20 000 dead or enslaved after the German onslaught. Rome's total defeat at Teutoberg halted their expansion permanently, and would be remembered as Rome’s greatest humiliation.

The Ulfhedinn is the unique Warrior replacement which only the Germans can train. It is much cheaper than the Warrior and gains an attack bonus against Barbarian Units. When a barbarian unit is defeated, the Ulfhedinn has a chance to convert the unit to your side. Converting barbarian units also increases your influence with the nearest city-state. Use Slaganz to hunt down barbarians and form a strong coalition of early city-state allies.

Cheap early-game warrior. Only Germany may build it. Much stronger against Barbarians, and has a chance of converting defeated Barbarian Units. Starts with [COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]Barbarian Alliance[ENDCOLOR] Promotion, allowing him to create faster Alliances with City-States.

Sofa

Ranged Unit excelling at supporting your cavalry. Only the Songhai may build it. Cheaper and available earlier than the Crossbowman, and all mounted units within two tiles receive a [ICON_STRENGTH] Combat boost. Starts with the [COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]Medic I[ENDCOLOR] Promotion.

The Sofa is a Songhai unique unit, replacing the Crossbowman. It serves as an excellent support unit starting with the Medic I promotion and a 15% Damage increase to all Mounted units within 2 tiles. The Sofa has lower offensive strength, but is relatively cheap to train and available earlier.

Sofa is a Mandinka term for slave soldiers who served in the army of the various Empires of West Africa. Originally, the Sofas were horse grooms of the soldier-nobility, the Farari, but their role slowly changed to become skirmishers and soldiers in their own right. Sofas were recruited from "jonow" (slaves) captured in battle or bought from afar. The institution of slavery in the Mali and Songhai Empires heavily rewarded loyalty, and jonow could rise to civil or military positions of prominence. Jonow became part of their master's clan, and were often freed after a certain amount of years.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE] Sofas were equipped with two quivers, and their bow was small by European standards, so sofas employed deadly poisons and fired in arcs to give their arrows strength.
SPAD S.VII

Potent Modern Era flying Unit. Only France may build it. Has a longer range and is slightly weaker than the Triplane it replaces. Starts with the [COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]Air Logistics[ENDCOLOR] Promotion. Requires [ICON_RES_OIL] Oil.
The SPAD S.VII is France's early air superiority fighter. These fighters will help create a strong French presence in the air with their ability to attack twice in a turn.

World War I saw rapid technological and tactical changes in how wars were fought, including the adoption of aircraft for scouting and bombing. These machines opened an entirely new theatre of war. Despite their promise, the first aircrafts were slow, clumsy, and unreliable due to their underpowered combustion engines. This all changed in 1915 when Marc Birgikt invented a new V8 engine boasting 150 horsepower and weighing only 330 pounds. The French high command saw the new motor's value as an aircraft engine and commissioned a new fighter aircraft: The Société Pour L'Aviation et ses Dérivés, or "SPAD" S. VII.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE] By late 1916, SPAD VIIs were beginning to see action, and were widely adopted by allied pilots for the rest of the war. Though lacking the maneuverability of older Nieuport fighters, the SPAD VII was unmatched in sheer speed, travelling in excess of 127mph and capable of diving at more than 249mph. Pilots created entirely new tactics to leverage this speed, which gave the SPAD the ability to safely avoid pitched battles. The added stability in diving was especially appreciated over the old Nieuports, which had a bad habit of shedding their wings during maneuvers.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE] Air superiority became a constant arms race against newer and better German designs and engines. By the end of the war, the SPAD VII's single .303 Vickers machine gun was outmatched by German fighters, which carried at least two machine guns. The heavier and faster SPAD XIII eventually replaced the SPAD VII by late 1917, and saw France through the remainder of the War. Despite its shortcomings, the SPAD series is remembered as one of the fastest and most powerful of WWI fighters.
Schützenstand

The Schützenstand were originally rifle guilds and rifle companies that had been formed in the 15th and 16th centuries and were regularly involved in military operations within the borders of the Austrian county of Tyrol. A Standschütze was a member of a Schützenstand ("shooting club"), into which he was enrolled, which automatically committed him to the voluntary military protection of the state of Tyrol (and Vorarlberg). In effect this made Standschützen a Tyrolean local militia and home guard.

The Schützenstand is an Austrian unique building, replacing the Arsenal. It is cheaper than the Arsenal and provides more defense. Increases the City's [ICON_RANGE_STRENGTH] Ranged Strike Range by 1, and also allows the City to Ranged Strike indirectly, ignoring Line of Sight. It allows for faster construction of land military units in the city. It also provides +1 [ICON_PRODUCTION] Production and +1 [ICON_CULTURE] Culture per city-state ally.

City must have a Castle. Military Units supplied by this City's population increased by 25%. Increases the City's [ICON_RANGE_STRENGTH] Ranged Strike Range by 1, and allows Indirect Fire.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Garrisoned units receive an additional 10 Health when healing in this city. Foreign Spies cannot steal [ICON_RESEARCH] Science from this City.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]+1 [ICON_PRODUCTION] Production and +1 [ICON_CULTURE] Culture for each City-State Ally. +30% [ICON_PRODUCTION] Production and 15 XP for Gunpowder Units, and +15% [ICON_PRODUCTION] Production to all other Land Military Units.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Empire [ICON_HAPPINESS_3] Needs Modifier is reduced by 5% in this City.
Steam Mill

Stationary steam engines are fixed steam engines used for pumping or driving mills and factories, and for power generation. They are distinct from locomotive engines used on railways, traction engines for heavy steam haulage on roads, steam cars (and other motor vehicles), agricultural engines used for ploughing or threshing, marine engines, and the steam turbines used as the mechanism of power generation for most nuclear power plants. They were introduced during the 18th century and widely made for the whole of the 19th century and most of the first half of the 20th century, only declining as electricity supply and the internal combustion engine became more widespread.

+1 [ICON_PRODUCTION] Production for every 2 [ICON_CITIZEN] Citizens in the City. +2 [ICON_PRODUCTION] Production for every Steam Mill on Empire. Manufactories worked by the City gain +4 [ICON_PRODUCTION] Production.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]2 Specialists in this City no longer produce [ICON_HAPPINESS_3] Unhappiness from Urbanization.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]When you complete a building from the Industrial Era or later, gain 10% of its construction cost as Points towards a [ICON_GREAT_ENGINEER] Great Engineer.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]+2 [ICON_PRODUCTION] Production to Engineer Specialists.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Nearby [ICON_RES_COAL] Coal: +3 [ICON_PRODUCTION] Production.

Unique English replacement for the Factory. The Steam Mill is cheaper, requires no [ICON_RES_COAL] Coal, is available earlier than the Factory, and provides additional Production to [ICON_RES_COAL] Coal worked by the City. The Steam Mill also provides [ICON_GREAT_ENGINEER] Great Engineer points when constructing buildings, while increasing the [ICON_PRODUCTION] Production of engineer specialists. Since Steam Mills do not require Coal, you can use your Coal surplus to build Seaports and ironclads, or you can trade it away for a large amount of gold.

City Receives a [COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]Free[ENDCOLOR] [ICON_RES_COCA] Coca Luxury Resource and 25 [ICON_FOOD] Food on Construction.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]15% of [ICON_FOOD] Food is carried over after a new [ICON_CITIZEN] Citizen is born.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Allows [ICON_FOOD] Food to be moved from this city along trade routes inside your civilization.[NEWLINE]Nearby [ICON_RES_WHEAT] Wheat: +1 [ICON_FOOD] Food.[NEWLINE]Nearby [ICON_RES_BANANA] Bananas: +1 [ICON_FOOD] Food.[NEWLINE]Nearby [ICON_RES_DEER] Deer: +1 [ICON_FOOD] Food.[NEWLINE]Nearby [ICON_RES_BISON] Bison: +1 [ICON_FOOD] Food.

The Qullqa is the unique Granary replacement for the Inca. In addition to the normal bonuses of a Granary, the Qullqa heals your garrisoned units every turn. On construction, a [ICON_RES_COCA] Coca Luxury Resource appears beneath the city. [ICON_RES_COCA] Coca replaces any existing resource that was below the city previously.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Coca increases the speed of constructing improvements, but also makes mountains passable to any civilization which controls it. Guard your Qullqa, so that other civilizations cannot follow your troops into the mountains.

Qullqa were storage silos located along roadsides near cities and political centers across the Tawantinsuyu. The vast network of Qullqa stored food and supplies for the military. Maintaining and stocking the Qullqa system fell to local lords who resided in military resupplying stations called Tambo, each located within a day's march of the next. This system relieved soldiers from the need to forage, but required constant maintenance from the local populace.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE] Royal Qullqa stored the luxury and ceremonial goods of the Incan nobility, including feathers, precious stones, and Coca leaves. Coca production was jealously guarded as an imperial monopoly; cultivation and distribution of coca was strictly under the control of the nobles and a few favored classes.
Coca

Coca is the leaf of any of four cultivated species of the family Erythroxylaceae native to western South America. The plant is famous for its various medicinal and nutritional uses, increasing alertness, dulling pain, supressing appetite, and treating altitude sickness. The leaves are traditionally chewed or brewed into a tea. Coca made an impression on the Spanish conquerors for its ability to help people work harder, even through exhaustion or hunger.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Today, coca is best known for its psychoactive alkaloid, cocaine. The alkaloid content of coca leaves is relatively low, requiring a large number of leaves for a single batch of cocaine. Coca leaf extract began being used in Coca-Cola products in 1885, but cocaine was completely eliminated from the products around 1903.

Tarkhan

Mounted warrior who supports Civilian and other Land Military Units with its unique abilities. Only the Huns may build it. Slightly cheaper than the Horseman it replaces. +1 Movement to [ICON_TEAM_1] Settlers and [ICON_WORKER] Workers that begin the turn stacked with this Unit and +20 HP to all adjacent friendly units whenever this unit pillages a tile.

The Tarkhan is the Hunnic unique replacement for the Horseman. Slightly cheaper than the Horseman, the Tarkhan can help to quickly spread your empire by increasing the movement of Settlers and Workers. Pillaging tiles with a Tarkhan heals all your adjacent units, which can be handy for healing a recently captured unit.

Tarkhan were nobles and high-ranking commanders within the armies of the Xiongnu and Hunnic empires. The term spread throughout the languages and peoples of the steppes, appearing as a title within Turkic, Mongol and Iranian cultures, even becoming a common boys name. Analogous to modern day generals, the Tarkhan were the protectors and conquerors of the Hunnic empire, spurring their civilization forward to greatness.
Tersane

When a Sea Trade Route originating here and targeting another Civilization is completed, receive a [ICON_TOURISM] Tourism boost with the Civilization based on your recent [ICON_CULTURE] Culture output.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]+50% [ICON_PRODUCTION] Production towards Cargo Ships and +30% [ICON_PRODUCTION] towards Naval Melee Units. Naval Melee Units trained in this City receive the [COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]Prize Ships[ENDCOLOR] Promotion.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]+1 [ICON_FOOD] Food from Coast and Ocean Tiles, +2 [ICON_FOOD] Food and +1 [ICON_PRODUCTION] Production from Sea Resources worked by this City.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]City must be on the coast.

Tersane is the unique Harbor replacement of the Ottomans. In addition to the bonuses of a Harbor, the Tersane increases the yields of work boats. The building also greatly improves production towards trade and military vessels, greatly improving the Ottoman's naval capabilities. All Melee Ships built in this city also receive the Prize Ships promotion, allowing them to capture defeated enemy units.

The Turkish word 'Tersane' is derived from the Venetian 'darsane', from which the English word 'arsenal' is also derived. Though never at the forefront of shipbuilding technology, the Ottomans enjoyed over a century of naval dominance in the Mediterranean following their conquest of Constantinople in 1453. The largest Tersane, constructed at the Golden Horn across from Constantinople, housed over 160 docks, drydocks, storehouses and supply depots, making it one of the largest centers of commerce and industry in the Mediterranean[NEWLINE][NEWLINE] Ottoman naval power was maintained through its tremendous shipbuilding capacity and its allegiances to the Barbary corsairs of North Africa. This pre-eminence was finally ended at the battle of Lepanto, where a combined Spanish and Venetian armada delivered a crushing defeat to the Ottomans, capturing or destroying more than two thirds of the Ottoman navy. In response, the Ottomans built 250 new vessels within six months.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE] "You come to see how we bear our misfortune. But I would have you know the difference between your loss and ours. In wresting Cyprus from you, we deprived you of an arm; in defeating our fleet, you have only shaved our beard."[NEWLINE] Grand Vizier Mehmed Sokullu, on the defeat at Lepanto, and the capture of Cyprus, which the Ottomans had taken earlier the same year
Teutonic Order

The Order of Brothers of the German House of Saint Mary in Jerusalem, more commonly known as the Teutonic Order, is a Catholic knightly order christened in 1190 in Acre, Jerusalem. Originally founded as an adjunct of the Knights Hospitaller, the Order was tasked with establishing hospitals and helping Germanic pilgrims on their way to the Holy Land. Within 50 years, the German Catholic order became a state unto itself, prosecuting a holy crusade against Baltic pagans from their capital in present day Malbork, Poland.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE] After Christian forces were expelled from Jerusalem, the Teutonic knights found work as mercenaries and guardsmen in Transylvania, Hungary, and then Poland, before becoming the largest player in a new Prussian Crusade against the pagan inhabitants of the Eastern Baltics. The Teutonic Order carried out a bloody, centuries-long campaign of forced conversions and ethnic replacement that brought them into conflict with Estonians, Lithuanians, Old Prussians and their former Polish allies. Resistance to forced Christianization by Catholic knights would shape the national identities of all these neighboring peoples.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE] The adoption of Christianity in Lithuania along with Poland's attempts to politically isolate the Teutonic Order from the rest of Catholicism left the Order without a purpose (and a shortage of friends) by 1520. In response, the Grand Master of the Order, Albert of Brandenburg, resigned from the Order, converted to Lutheranism, and styled himself Duke of Prussia. With the consent of the Order, Albert converted their land holdings into a secularized fiefdom, making Prussia the first Protestant state. Though declining in political force, the Teutonic Order continued to exist as a Catholic state through its holdings in Germania until forcibly dissolved by Napoleon Bonaparte in 1809. The Teutonic Order eventually reformed and still exists today as a ceremonial and charitable organization.

The Teutonic Order is Germany's unique wonder, replacing the Heroic Epic. This wonder provides strong bonuses to all cities in your empire with a Barracks comparable to that of a full Order. All new units trained in any city with a Barracks receive the Morale promotion for free.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]With this wonder, Germany is able to found and reform much more easilly and quickly than other civilizations.

Does not require a Barracks. Grants a [COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]Free[ENDCOLOR] Barracks in the City. A [COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]Free[ENDCOLOR] Great Writer appears near the city. Contains 1 slot for a [ICON_GREAT_WORK] Great Work of Writing. [NEWLINE][NEWLINE]All Castles gain +2 [ICON_PRODUCTION] Production and all Barracks in the Empire gain +2 [ICON_PEACE] Faith, +3 [ICON_STRENGTH] Defense, and +50 HP. Units trained in a City with a Barracks gain the [COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]Morale[ENDCOLOR] Promotion. [NEWLINE][NEWLINE]15 [ICON_PEACE] Faith whenever you kill an enemy Unit, scaling with Era. Enables you to select a Reformation Belief at 5% below its normal Global [ICON_RELIGION] Follower requirement (20% on Standard). Tophet
Gain +20 [ICON_CULTURE] Culture in the City whenever a Unit is purchased, scaling with Era. Units purchased in this City receive additional experience.

The Tophet is the unique Shrine replacement for Carthage. In addition to the normal bonuses of a Shrine, the Tophet provides Culture whenever a unit is purchased in the City. Military Units purchased in a City with a Tophet gain +5XP at normal speed, giving them a small boost before barracks, and mitigating the experience penalty on purchased units slightly.

"Tophet" is a Hebrew term for a place of worship and human sacrifice to the Canaanite gods, and has become a colorful synonym for hell within Judeo-Christian theology. Usually located outside cities, Tophets were holy places where sacrifices to the gods could be presented to the heads of the Phoenician pantheon, Ba'al Hammon and his consort, Tanit.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Regular sacrifices were made to ensure the prosperity of Carthage and the ashes of burnt offerings were sealed within the Tophet. Child sacrifice, once prevalent throughout the Near-East, was a persistent hallmark of Carthaginian religious life long after contemporary cultures had shunned the practice. Modern archaeological evidence suggests children were sacrificed in times of great stress such as wars, plagues, and natural disasters as an act of divine supplication.
University of Coimbra

Opened in 1290, the University of Coimbra is one of the oldest centers of higher learning in the world, and the oldest in Portugal. The university was founded by King Dinis as the Lisbon Estudo Geral, originally with faculties of Arts, Law, Canon Law and Medicine. As the only university in Portugal for 350 years, the University of Coimbra became a focus of educational, political, and social influence in Portugal.

The Universiy of Coimbra is the unique Portuguese replacement for the Oxford University. It does not require a University, and provides a free University in the city. In addition to the normal bonuses of the Oxford University, it gives all naval units the ability to gain gold from exploration, and generates Gold and Production in the city for every Feitoria built in foreign lands.

Does not require a University in the City. Provides a [COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]Free[ENDCOLOR] [ICON_GREAT_SCIENTIST] Great Scientist and a University on Completion. All Universities gain +3 [ICON_GOLD] Gold. +50 [ICON_CULTURE] Culture every time you research a Technology, scaling with Era. -1 [ICON_HAPPINESS_3] Unhappiness from [ICON_RESEARCH] Illiteracy.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]All Naval Units gain the [COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]Age of Discovery[ENDCOLOR] Promotion. Waag

When you spend [ICON_GOLD] Gold to purchase Units or invest in Buildings in this City, 15% of the cost is converted into [ICON_RESEARCH] Science.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Caravansaries and Customs Houses in the City gain +3 [ICON_GOLD] Gold. +1 [ICON_GOLD] Gold, [ICON_CULTURE] Culture, and [ICON_PRODUCTION] Production in this City for every Global Monopoly on Empire.[NEWLINE]Nearby [ICON_RES_GOLD] Gold: +3 [ICON_GOLD] Gold.[NEWLINE]Nearby [ICON_RES_SILVER] Silver: +1 [ICON_GOLD] Gold, +1 [ICON_PRODUCTION] Production, +1 [ICON_CULTURE] Culture.[NEWLINE]Nearby [ICON_RES_GEMS] Gems: +2 [ICON_CULTURE] Culture, +1 [ICON_GOLD] Gold.

The Waag is the Netherlands' unique replacement for the Bank. In addition to the normal bonuses of a Bank, the Waag comes earlier and provides bonuses to Defense and Production. The Waag's bonuses scale with the total number of global monopolies, both luxury and strategic that the Dutch control. Trade and conquer vigorously to leverage your Waag's potential strengths.

A Waag ("weigh house") was a public building in which goods were weighed for market. Prior to international standards of weights and measures, the Waags performed an indispensable service in preventing the fraudulent sale of goods. Waags were operated by local authorities who would also use them for the levying of taxes on goods transported through or sold within the city. This necessitated weigh houses be near a market square or town centre.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Of particular note is the Amsterdam Waag, built in the 15th-century on Nieuwmarkt square in Amsterdam. A number of guilds were housed on the top floors of the building: the blacksmiths' guild, the painter's guild, the masons' guild and the surgeons' guild, each with its own entrance gate. In 1632 Rembrandt van Rijn was commissioned to paint the surgeons at work; the resulting painting, ‘The Anatomy Lesson of Dr. Nicolaes Tulp’, made his reputation.

Xiafan Guanjun

Sturdy Renaissance Era Naval Ranged Unit. Only China may build it. Generates [ICON_INFLUENCE] Influence every turn when stationed in a City-State's borders. Has the [COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]Broadside[ENDCOLOR] Promotion for free.

The Xiafan Guanjun is a Chinese unique unit. It is much sturdier than the Frigate it replaces, and is available earlier. You can use your Xiafan Guanjun to passively bring city-states under your sway, or take advantage of its bonus against cities and dominate coastal empires.

The Xiafan Guanjun (lit. "The Foreign Expeditionary Armada") was the great treasure fleet of the Ming Dynasty. At the behest of Emperor Zhu Di, the legendary admiral Zheng He headed seven voyages between 1405 and 1433 AD. The Xiafan Guanjun ranged as far as the Arabian Peninsula in their task of projecting Chinese influence abroad, bringing many smaller nations under the suzerainty of China.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE] The Xiafan Guanjun had some of the largest wooden ships ever constructed, some measuring up to 416 feet in length. It would be another century before European ships could match the size and power of China’s fleet, making them the undisputed naval superpower of the 15th century. Despite their superiority, Zheng He’s voyages were primarily diplomatic, bringing envoys and even kings before the emperor to present tribute and perform the 'kowtow', a ritual act of reverence and subservience.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE] "As an engine for carrying man and his commerce upon the high and stormy seas as well as on the vast inland waterways, it is doubtful if any class of vessel… is more suited or better adapted to its purpose than the Chinese or Indian junk, and it is certain that for flatness of sail and handiness, the Chinese rig is unsurpassed."[NEWLINE]-H. Warington Smyth

Yamato

Powerful Naval Ranged Unit. Only Japan may build it. Has more range, power and higher defense than the Battleship it replaces. Earns [ICON_GREAT_ADMIRAL] Great Admiral Points on kills.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Receive +600 [ICON_GOLDEN_AGE] Golden Age Points whenever a Yamato is constructed.[NEWLINE]Enemies receive +400 [ICON_CULTURE] Culture and +400 [ICON_GOLDEN_AGE] Golden Age Points whenever they destroy a Yamato.

The Yamato is the unique Battleship replacement for Japan which is significantly more powerful. It has increased range, attack, strength, defense against attack and earns Great Admiral Points on kills. Use them to dominate the seas in the end game, giving you the edge for a Domination Victory.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE] Each Yamato gives points towards a Golden Age when constructed, but sinking a Yamato rewards enemies with Golden Age points and Culture, so don't leave your Yamatos without an escort.

The Yamato-class battleships were the crown jewel of the Imperial Japanese Navy during World War II. Displacing 73,000 tonnes at full load, the vessels were the heaviest and most powerfully armed battleships ever constructed. Each Yamato carried nine 18.1 inch guns, the largest naval artillery ever fitted to a warship, each capable of firing 3,000 lb. shells over 26 miles. Two battleships of the class, Yamato and Musashi, were completed while a third, Shinano, was converted to an aircraft carrier during construction. All were sunk by American forces during WWII.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Due to their size, speed, and power, The Yamato-class visibly embodied Japan's determination and readiness to defend its interests against the western powers, especially the United States. One of the reasons that the warship may have such significance in Japanese culture is that the word "Yamato" was often used as a poetic name for Japan itself. Thus, the construction and destruction of the Yamato battleships became symbolic for the rise and fall of Japanese imperial aspirations.

Yassa Court

Automatically constructed in all [COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]Unoccupied Cities[ENDCOLOR] after discovering Philosophy.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Eliminates [ICON_OCCUPIED] Extra Unhappiness from an Occupied City. +20% [ICON_PRODUCTION] Production towards Ranged, Siege, Mounted and Armor Military Units. +10 [ICON_RESEARCH] Science, [ICON_CULTURE]Culture, and [ICON_GOLD] Gold for every Yassa Court on Empire whenever you Conquer a City, scaling with Era.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Illiteracy, Boredom, and Empire [ICON_HAPPINESS_3] Needs Modifier is reduced by 1% in all Cities. Building cost is slightly increased with number of Cities.

Unique Mongolian replacement for the Courthouse. Is automatically built in non-occupied Cities. In addition to eliminating Unhappiness in Occupied Cities, this building reduces global unhappiness from Illiteracy and Boredom, and increases production of all Land-based military units, except Unmounted Melee. Conquering Cities triggers a small amount of Gold, Science and Culture in every city. It is also slightly cheaper than the Courthouse.

Yassa was a secret written code of law created by Genghis Khan. The word Yassa translates into "order" or "decree". It was the de facto law of the Mongol Empire even though the "law" was never actually made public. The Yassa seems to have originated from decrees issued in war time, and was later codified and expanded to include cultural and life-style conventions. By keeping the Yassa secret, the decrees could be modified and used selectively. It is believed that the Yassa was supervised by Genghis Khan himself with the help of the high judge of the Mongol Empire: His stepbrother, Shihihutag. Genghis Khan appointed his second son Chagatai (a.k.a. Chagatai Khan) to oversee the execution of the laws.

Yellow Brow

Tenacious Renaissance Era Unit. Only the Shoshone may build it. Has the [COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]Anti-cavalry[ENDCOLOR] Promotion, fights at full strength when damaged, and has double combat bonus from fortifying.

The Yellow Brow is unmatched for its ability to hold ground. Never one to retreat, the Yellow brow fights at full strength regardless of health, and has double the normal bonus from fortifying. This unit is very effective against enemy cavalry

Yellow Brows (Sh. Ohamupe) were one of two military societies within the Shoshone, playing an integral role in hunting, scouting, and policing within their bands. Yellow Brow braves shaved their heads into a cockscomb 'mohawk', and painted their exposed heads yellow, hence their common English name.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE] The Yellow Brows were composed of only the bravest and most daring of the young men, tasked with keeping order on hunting expeditions, scouting, and soldiering. The Society never had more than a few hundred members at a time; members elected their replacement upon graduation. A young Yellow Brow was expected to act and speak in a contrarian way as a sign of membership. For instance, when asked if he would like to join the Yellow Brows, it was expected that the young man would say 'No' as a sign of willingness to join, or 'Yes' if he wished to decline.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE] In battle, Yellow Brows were led by a war chief who carried a long cane tipped with a stone or metal dagger. The cane was used to grab and unhorse opponents, or as a No-Retreat signal. If the enemy was gaining the upper hand, the chief would drive his staff into the ground and the braves would defend him to the last. Yellow Brows were banned from leaving their chief's side until another member of the tribe came and released the braves from their charge. Deserting the chief was met with abject mockery, and often resulted in banishment from the tribe.
